results.name: ADFS
results.description: ADFS System review - Shoring up the existing state to end of life (EOL).

criterias.name: Ad-hoc attempts by individual contributors to perform application and environment vulnerability scanning and penetration testing.
criterias.definition: Ad-hoc attempts by individual contributors to perform application and environment vulnerability scanning and penetration testing.

criterias.name: Adhoc tooling is available to assist in pinpointing the root cause of issues
criterias.definition: Adhoc tooling is available to assist in pinpointing the root cause of issues

criterias.name: Adoption of some Disaster Recovery tooling at individual team level to track and automate aspects of the Disaster Recovery processes.
criterias.definition: Adoption of some Disaster Recovery tooling at individual team level to track and automate aspects of the Disaster Recovery processes.

criterias.name: Alignment metrics are collected consistently and improvements goals are set.
criterias.definition: Alignment metrics are collected consistently and improvements goals are set.

criterias.name: Alignment metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes.
criterias.definition: Alignment metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes.

criterias.name: At least 1 production-like test environment is traversed in the SDLC
criterias.definition: At least 1 production-like test environment is traversed in the SDLC

criterias.name: At least one non-production environment is available for testing purposes.
criterias.definition: At least one non-production environment is available for testing purposes.

criterias.name: Attempts to establish design principles initially at individual team level.
criterias.definition: Attempts to establish design principles initially at individual team level.

criterias.name: Availability metrics are collected consistently and improvement goals are set with relation to SLA and SLOs.
criterias.definition: Availability metrics are collected consistently and improvement goals are set with relation to SLA and SLOs.

criterias.name: Availability metrics are compared with SLAs and SLOs.
criterias.definition: Availability metrics are compared with SLAs and SLOs.

criterias.name: Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability.
criterias.definition: Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability.

criterias.name: Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.
criterias.definition: Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.

criterias.name: Availability requirements are collected in adhoc manner and are not quantified.
criterias.definition: Availability requirements are collected in adhoc manner and are not quantified.

criterias.name: Basic or bespoke tools are used for availability testing and monitoring.
criterias.definition: Basic or bespoke tools are used for availability testing and monitoring.

criterias.name: Basic release tooling exists within team siloes. For example, spreadsheets, or whiteboards.
criterias.definition: Basic release tooling exists within team siloes. For example, spreadsheets, or whiteboards.

criterias.name: Basic tooling to track Disaster Recovery testing such as Excel or whiteboard.
criterias.definition: Basic tooling to track Disaster Recovery testing such as Excel or whiteboard.

criterias.name: Builds are created or deployment artefacts are acquired in a repeatable process that is established and followed group-wide.
criterias.definition: Builds are created or deployment artefacts are acquired in a repeatable process that is established and followed group-wide.
criterias.comment: Binaries are sometimes installed through SCCM / Microsoft O/S patching, and sometimes via manual download from Microsoft. No mention of checksum verifications or dependency scanning.

criterias.name: Changes can be made to the system with predictable turnaround, and minimal risk
criterias.definition: Changes can be made to the system with predictable turnaround, and minimal risk

criterias.name: Clear role definitions exist at least within individual teams.
criterias.definition: Clear role definitions exist at least within individual teams.

criterias.name: Communications channels and methods during an incident are well understood across the team
criterias.definition: Communications channels and methods during an incident are well understood across the team
criterias.comment: Asset outage will impact "bank standard" communication channels, this asset needs to plan around alternative/unimpacted communication channels.

criterias.name: Consistent role definitions are emerging within teams.
criterias.definition: Consistent role definitions are emerging within teams.
criterias.comment: Segregation of duties is NOT enforced for releases. ADFS team perform TVT, O365 team perform BVT. The change management process does enforce oversight, but this does not ensure the overseer is intimately familiar with the technical nature of each change.

criterias.name: Cost per incident is well understood (can be modelled, for example, via T&M)
criterias.definition: Cost per incident is well understood (can be modelled, for example, via T&M)

criterias.name: DR Optimisation is a key goal that regularly feeds back into the SDLC and architecture decisions.
criterias.definition: DR Optimisation is a key goal that regularly feeds back into the SDLC and architecture decisions.

criterias.name: DR plans extended for service-specific scenarios, along with regular rehearsals. Plans include reduced capacity, partial failure scenarios. For example - reduced compute, reduced memory, network partitioning. The segmentation between "Availability" and "Disaster Recovery" becomes fluid.
criterias.definition: DR plans extended for service-specific scenarios, along with regular rehearsals. Plans include reduced capacity, partial failure scenarios. For example - reduced compute, reduced memory, network partitioning. The segmentation between "Availability" and "Disaster Recovery" becomes fluid.

criterias.name: Data and metrics to track change lead time against estimated complexity and impact is readily available
criterias.definition: Data and metrics to track change lead time against estimated complexity and impact is readily available

criterias.name: Defined 'categories' or 'severities' of incidents, with a clear understanding of what each category means for this service
criterias.definition: Defined 'categories' or 'severities' of incidents, with a clear understanding of what each category means for this service

criterias.name: Disaster Recovery capability is highly dependent on the skill and knowledge of key people within the team. Disaster recovery plans may exist and may be practiced, but not in a consistent way.
criterias.definition: Disaster Recovery capability is highly dependent on the skill and knowledge of key people within the team. Disaster recovery plans may exist and may be practiced, but not in a consistent way.

criterias.name: Disaster recovery metrics are available and but may not be consistently collected. Some key metrics are collected and published across the organisation with dependencies between systems.
criterias.definition: Disaster recovery metrics are available and but may not be consistently collected. Some key metrics are collected and published across the organisation with dependencies between systems.

criterias.name: Disaster recovery metrics are available, and inform decisions within the team.
criterias.definition: Disaster recovery metrics are available, and inform decisions within the team.

criterias.name: Disaster recovery metrics such as time to switch to a Disaster Recovery site are captured consistently across the organisation. Metrics include end-to-end recovery of the service, time to switch for upstream and downstream systems. These metrics can be used to measure adherance to SLAs.
criterias.definition: Disaster recovery metrics such as time to switch to a Disaster Recovery site are captured consistently across the organisation. Metrics include end-to-end recovery of the service, time to switch for upstream and downstream systems. These metrics can be used to measure adherance to SLAs.

criterias.name: Disaster recovery plans are regularly rehearsed, with end-to-end target timelines, and timings against all sub-tasks.
criterias.definition: Disaster recovery plans are regularly rehearsed, with end-to-end target timelines, and timings against all sub-tasks.

criterias.name: Environments with minimal production parity are readily available for testing and verification purposes
criterias.definition: Environments with minimal production parity are readily available for testing and verification purposes

criterias.name: Escaped defects are RCA'd, with test suites updated accordingly.
criterias.definition: Escaped defects are RCA'd, with test suites updated accordingly.

criterias.name: Explicit understanding of what is not and cannot be tested (blind spots) - e.g. via code coverage and other tools.
criterias.definition: Explicit understanding of what is not and cannot be tested (blind spots) - e.g. via code coverage and other tools.

criterias.name: Failed change post release reviews feed back through the SDLC or vendor process. Similarly, successful changes are analysed for key accelerants.
criterias.definition: Failed change post release reviews feed back through the SDLC or vendor process. Similarly, successful changes are analysed for key accelerants.

criterias.name: Following of secure coding principles for communication, data storage, authentication and authorisation is dependant on the efforts of key inviduals.
criterias.definition: Following of secure coding principles for communication, data storage, authentication and authorisation is dependant on the efforts of key inviduals.

criterias.name: Formalised process that is followed across the organisation
criterias.definition: Formalised process that is followed across the organisation

criterias.name: Generic Operating models used by the  business.

criterias.name: Graduate/Pipeline intake specific to sector requirements taking place.

criterias.definition: Group-wide availability testing processes are established and followed. Representative test environments are used consistently for availability testing.

criterias.definition: Standards for documenting dependencies between modules are emerging at individual team level. Some impact assessment is performed.

criterias.name: Standards for documenting module boundaries (APIs, etc.) are emerging at individual team level.
criterias.definition: Standards for documenting module boundaries (APIs, etc.) are emerging at individual team level.

criterias.name: Standards for the development process from requirements to implementation are emerging at the individual team level. Functional and non-functional requirements and constraints are documented with some consistency.
criterias.definition: Standards for the development process from requirements to implementation are emerging at the individual team level. Functional and non-functional requirements and constraints are documented with some consistency.

criterias.name: Structured approach to problem analysis and capture of detail as tailored for the team
criterias.definition: Structured approach to problem analysis and capture of detail as tailored for the team

criterias.name: Subject matter experts forming within teams though belonging to larger expert domains. Required skills are identified
criterias.definition: Subject matter experts forming within teams though belonging to larger expert domains. Required skills are identified

criterias.name: Subject specific training outsourced with some internal BU support
criterias.definition: Subject specific training outsourced with some internal BU support

criterias.name: Succession planning with program forming internally to assist internal staff progression
criterias.definition: Succession planning with program forming internally to assist internal staff progression

criterias.name: Teams organized around all capabilities; Cross functional Training; Graduate intake
criterias.definition: Teams organized around all capabilities; Cross functional Training; Graduate intake

criterias.name: Test activities and assets are further segregated appropriately with respect to different focusses - e.g. integration, functional, performance.
criterias.definition: Test activities and assets are further segregated appropriately with respect to different focusses - e.g. integration, functional, performance.

criterias.name: Test case failures act as an automated gate for further activity - e.g. through a failed build or a failed deployment
criterias.definition: Test case failures act as an automated gate for further activity - e.g. through a failed build or a failed deployment

criterias.name: Test completion reports are produced to drive go/no-go decisions per change
criterias.definition: Test completion reports are produced to drive go/no-go decisions per change

criterias.name: Test scenarios lead to the development of automated and scripted tests, with very few exceptions.
criterias.definition: Test scenarios lead to the development of automated and scripted tests, with very few exceptions.

criterias.name: Testing and development are performed by independent parties
criterias.definition: Testing and development are performed by independent parties
criterias.comment: The only testing that is performed by a different team is BVT, everything else is done by the same team, often the same Engineer.

criterias.name: Testing effort per change or release is predictable
criterias.definition: Testing effort per change or release is predictable

criterias.name: Testing is fully integrated into all parts of the SDLC
criterias.definition: Testing is fully integrated into all parts of the SDLC

criterias.name: Testing is integrated into core parts of the SDLC
criterias.definition: Testing is integrated into core parts of the SDLC

criterias.name: Tests are repeatable, automated and regular and tied into the build/release process, with very few exceptions.
criterias.definition: Tests are repeatable, automated and regular and tied into the build/release process, with very few exceptions.

criterias.name: The majority of test cases and test scenarios are executed automatically, with statistics logged to one or more centralised stores
criterias.definition: The majority of test cases and test scenarios are executed automatically, with statistics logged to one or more centralised stores

criterias.name: The operation team's integration with the broader organisational change management process, and the maturity of tooling used to actuate change with minimal risk.
criterias.definition: The operation team's integration with the broader organisational change management process, and the maturity of tooling used to actuate change with minimal risk.

criterias.name: The tooling and processes enabling ops  to respond appropriately to incidents and align with broader incident management frameworks throughout the organisation. Furthermore, the degree of tie-in with respect to incident management and the SDLC.
criterias.definition: The tooling and processes enabling ops  to respond appropriately to incidents and align with broader incident management frameworks throughout the organisation. Furthermore, the degree of tie-in with respect to incident management and the SDLC.
criterias.comment: Still using SCOM. Appropriate tooling should ensure incidents are responded to and resolved within the defined SLAs, the recent P1 indicates this may not be the case.

criterias.name: Tooling to support security analysis is local to the team or the efforts of individual practitioners.
criterias.definition: Tooling to support security analysis is local to the team or the efforts of individual practitioners.

criterias.name: Training budget allocated for skills improvement within teams
criterias.definition: Training budget allocated for skills improvement within teams

criterias.name: Training supported through business time budget and cost budget allocation
criterias.definition: Training supported through business time budget and cost budget allocation

criterias.name: Unmanaged attrition rate being informed
criterias.definition: Unmanaged attrition rate being informed

criterias.definition: Well-established metrics for incident response - e.g. time to first response, MTTD, MTTR, no. of escalations (e.g. L1 to L2)

criterias.definition: Well-established metrics for overall service health, including volume and severity of incidents

criterias.name: Well-established metrics, with targets for continuous improvement.
criterias.definition: Well-established metrics, with targets for continuous improvement.

finalReport.title:
Lab49 Health Assessment
{{.Project.Name}}
finalReport.content: Produced by Lab49 on {{.Now.Format "2006 January 06"}}, <hr size="5" class="bg-lab opacity-10">

finalReport.title: Introduction
finalReport.content:
{{.Project.Client.Name}}’s {{.Project.Name}} has been identified as a critical Group application. Recent P2 incidents have and continue to occur directly impacting the availability of banking services reliant on channels which make use of the EP system for orchestration; workflow; and integration of services.
  
The focus of this report is the {{.Project.Client.Name}}. This platform performs the following main roles :
* ***Role 1***
* ***Role 2***
* ***Role 3***

The engagement was conducted over a six-week period by Lab49.  The assessment team engaged directly with the various teams within CBA to understand the current technology platform landscape and validate findings against a bespoke Health Assessment Framework to determine CBA’s maturity with respect to the avoidance of P1 and P2 incidents as the Enterprise platform approaches its end of life in **September 2022**.

finalReport.title: Scope
finalReport.content: The scope of the review covers the maturity and health of the {{.Project.Name}} platform. *The review puts specific focus on stability, reliability and recovery from incidents or issues and the overall portability of the platform beyond the end of life. Special consideration is given to consumers of the platform and their resulting experience. The findings provide an actionable path to improvement*

finalReport.title: Methodology
finalReport.content:
Lab49’s Health Assessment Framework is derived from deep exposure to many of the industry’s largest technology platforms; it provides a standardised approach that can be deployed widely across CBA systems to deliver consistent and comparable results. To derive meaningful results across a variety of platforms, the optimised framework primarily takes a 360-degree view of platform maturity including technology, people, process, and data. The purpose of this review is to assess the {{.Project.Name}} maturity, stability, integrity and performance throughout the run-to-retire phase as data is possibly migrated onto new platforms. The findings from this exercise should be read not only as an assessment of the current state of the system but also provide an actionable path to improvement. Furthermore, it should be noted that to achieve higher levels of maturity ({{.Project.Score.Global}} and up) requires coordinated, cross-organisational effort. The assessment framework is based upon a scoring measure across a 5-point scale as an objective indicator to assess system maturity and complexity. The Framework is based upon the following maturity levels:
Level Title Description
1 Initial Success depends on the competence and efforts of key individuals.
2 Developing Team-wide process discipline is in place. Processes are repeatable within the context of a team.
3 Defined Standards are set and used across multiple teams. Organisation-wide initiatives provide meaningful uplift to teams.
4 Measurable Critical aspects of processes emanate metrics and data with high levels of automation. Processes are quantified and controlled.
5 Optimising Process improvement goals are quantified and measured for continuous improvement.
For this review, the following {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics have been identified as key measures for assessing system health:
    {{range .Project.Topics}}
  1. {{.Name}}
    2. {{end}}
Within each of these {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics is a detailed set of measures which have been assessed against the 5-point maturity scale. The assessment of each topic has resulted in an aggregated maturity level for that topic, providing an objective summary view of the overall system maturity.

finalReport.title: Assessment Topics
Scoring Method
finalReport.content:
There are 2 types of scores that the assessment produces: 1. Topic score: this is a score per topic area. Its intent is to communicate relative strength and focus areas across several topics. 2. Overall score: this is a score for the overall assessment. Its intent is to provide upper-level management a general sense of how the service is performing. The method used to devise each of the above scores is detailed in the following sub-sections.

Topic Score

The topic score focusses on providing a relative health measure for each topic area, such as Availability and Performance. It is expressed as a number between 0 and 5.

Method overview

For each topic, there are several criteria. Each criterion is associated with a maturity level (0 through to 5). Some example criteria are in the following Worked Example sub-section. When performing an assessment on a topic, each criterion is given a rating. Each rating, along with its associated score value is listed below: * Not met (0) * Partially met (0.5) * Met or Exceeded (1) This provides us with the following interim values for the topic: * A max maturity for the assessment: this is one level below the maturity of the first occurrence of a “Not Met” criteria. This is based upon the rationale that a topic’s current maturity should always fall short of the first observed unmet criteria. * A base score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias up to the max maturity * The base number of criteria : number of criterias forming the base raw score * An extended score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias above max maturity * The extended number of criteria : number of criterias forming the extended raw score The final score for this topic is then calculated as follows: (base score / base number of criteria * max maturity) + (extended score/extended number of criterias) The final score is then rounded to 1 decimal point. The following sub-section walks through a worked example. Worked Example Below is a slimmed down version of the criteria for Availability topic for example purposes. It also contains a rating per topic for an example assessment:

Maturity LevelCriteriaRating
1Roles are assigned in ad-hoc manner.Met or exceeded (1)
1Availability requirements are collected in ad-hoc manner and are not quantified.Met or exceeded (1)
2Initial attempts to assign roles across development team, solution architecture and architecture review board. Basic consistency on across projects exists.Met or exceeded (1)
2Operational standards are being established with respect to availability, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.Met or exceeded (1)
3Group-wide roles across development team, solution architecture, architecture review board are defined and followed.Partially met (0.5)
3Group-wide requirements process for availability is established and followed. It includes specification of quantifiable availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are established.Partially met (0.5)
4Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.Not met (0)
5Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability. Partially met (0.5)
In this example, the interim values are: * Max maturity: 3 (the first criteria with “Not met” is a Level 4 criteria, therefore max maturity becomes 3). * Base score: 5 * Base number of criteria : 6 * Extended score : 0.5 * Extended number of criteria: 2 Therefore, the final topic score, in this example, works out to be: (5 / 6) * 3 + (0.5/2) = 2.75

Overall Score

The overall score is a simple average over the score of each topic. Supposing a given assessment yields the following topic scores:
TopicMaturity Level
Availability Developing(2.7)
Performance Developing(2.6)
Scalability Developing(2)
Maintainability Developing(3.3)
Security Defined(3.7)
Organisational Architectural Alignment Developing(1.9)
SDLC Process Initial(2.6)
Change Management Defined(2.8)
Incident Management Defined(2)
Disaster Recovery Defined(3.4)
For such an assessment, the overall score becomes 2.7.

questionnaires.name: Testability
questionnaires.description: The degree to which a software system or a unit thereof supports its own testing, including the repeatability, automation and the accurate and timely reporting of the results.

questions.definition: Are there automated tests for reconciliations, if so what types and when are they run?
questions.answer:
So there are no automated tests for reconciliations, but there is an automated app with a job.
In order to do a test on the lower environment, we need to do a manual file copy and then we can trigger that job.
There is no automated test for that.

questions.definition: Are there performance tests to ensure production environment can process load and has capacity?
questions.answer: We have got a staging environment which has the same configuration as production. It's half the memory but in past testing we have seen that not making a difference between the production and the lower environment. So the file load should should give us exactly same degree of certainty.

questions.definition: At least one production-like test environment is traversed in the SDLC?
questions.answer: So we were using the test environment for doing the performance section.

questions.definition: Is performance testing part of environment upgrades?
questions.answer:
So there was only the load testing that was supposed to be done.
Performance testing but not not on the Web client.
only on the file loads

questions.definition: Can a reconciliation under development be tested against production-type volumes?
questions.answer:
Yes, we can test it
When it's a new development, we cannot.
Only for an existing one. We can test it and we can see how much is there any difference with the file load.

questionnaires.name: Availability
questionnaires.description: The ability of a system to generate or obtain required artifacts to provide assurance that the system is safe, data integrity is maintained and the system is operating effectively.  Compliance with all requirements including standards, policies, laws and service level agreements (SLA)

questions.definition: How does your team and system define “availability”?
questions.answer:
Planned outages are not classed as unavailable.
Tier 1 availability 99.98

Availability reports in service management collected on monthly or quarterly basis.

questions.definition: Are you tracking any availability metrics and data?
questions.answer:
Availability and capacity reports for all services.
Collected using splunk. 
Scon alerts from heartbeat events.
in cba all services have default level of monitoring heartbeat for site outages.
Outages trigger incident to flight deck or application support teams, part of service offering.

questions.definition:
Are you using any tools or processes to test and monitor availability? Are these integrated with group-wide tooling and metrics? 
a.	Integration with third-parties — e.g., Verizon
b.	Cloud and On-Premise.
questions.answer:
AWS one cloud.
Monitor yes, test unsure.
Monitor app dynamics and splunk to log it

questions.definition: Do you have any availability goals derived from business SLAs/SLOs?
questions.answer:
Tiering dictates availability, recoverability ,cyber (data classification)  arc 
i.e. criticality

questions.answer: Tier 1 availability

questions.definition: What testing processes and environments do you have in place? Do your test environments topologically mirror production?
questions.answer:
Believe we've got build Dev.
You have a UAT.
Staging and then prod NDR.

From a configuration perspective? UM, yes, but they might be normally our our staging environment is the one that's comes close to production.

Itself is the same as what's in prod, but data wise it would be either sanitized or whether it's a cut down version, because we can't. That's that's one of our controls that we can't have production data in the lower environment apart from staging.

I understood , so you sanitize or anonymized the data that's going into these different tests, right?
Correct, yeah, we scramble it, sanitize it as long as nothing because it it is a highly sensitive information. You've got account numbers and and personal.
Some details not. So along those lines, yeah.

questionnaires.name: Change Management
questionnaires.description: The alignment to a defined organisational process that enables an application to transition from a current state to a desired state.  The maturity of tooling used to actuate change of state with minimal risk.

questions.definition: Does your team follow CBA's group-wide change management standards?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.definition: Can you walk us through your usual change implementation process and steps from inception till production?
questions.answer:
5 step change process.
Logged in myservice ticketing tool.
Changes raised follow normal SDLC assess ... build, test & implementation approvers.
Also tracked in jira with tests cases.
Weekly cab change approval board.
Accurate change every 2 weeks.

questions.definition:
Please describe the type of changes that make up your change pipeline (patching, release, code changes, configuration changes, etc.)
a.	For vendor-provided assets, please describe the process of how new versions of software are received from the vendor.
questions.answer:
App changes: new recs , new matching rules for existing recs to make it more automated, new data feeder or new source to a rec are discussed with business , tested and then go to production.

Scheduling changes outside the application, autosys and batch changes, are not very frequent.
e.g. a new rec will have 3 separate changes 
. rec configuration
. rec source
. batch and autosys scheduling
All 3 implemented on same day ( only thursdays after 8 pm).

Patches goes through same change process ( outside Ali and Brahma's teams)
Changes raised in myservices & documented.
Test plan, cases & strategy in jira.
Signed off & then implemented.

Using SDLC process and testing minimum standard.
Have started using SDLC 2 standard this year (goes up to SDLC 4).

Vendor informs CBA about patches , sending all documentation.

questions.definition: Are you following the same process for all components (e.g. HSM firmware updates and internally developed code)?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.definition:
What type of testing do you perform? (e.g. performance, DR, functional, integration, unit)
a.	Is the level of testing performed varied per change? If so - how is the level of testing determined?
b.	How is this responsibility shared across teams?
questions.answer:
If patching, change will do all testing.
If reconciliation then end to end unit testing to application boundaries.
NFR testing are part of overall test strategy.

How to be sure of capacity?
As part of initial impact assessment, ask what volume is and have to find optimal time slot when can load file and ask when they want it completed by. if team has lots of recs, question will actually need the new rec. 
Accurate is running 23 hours a day, very chatty.
Testing standards don't vary. 
5 days of rigorous testing in UAT or test, encapsulating quality of data.
With larger project e.g. NPP then test more that 4 to 5 weeks.
Most new recs are part of a larger project, have to follow their requirements.
Recent upgrade had 2 to 3 months testing, had to test every account 3 to 4 hundred, 600 files per day.
XXXX manual not automated?
Ali's team is dev team build in Accurate.
Brahma's team is tech partner.
For new rec Ali's team will give Brahma's team requirements to automate the file load.
Then trigger end to end testing. 
Run loading then matching,
Ali's team will verify.
Investigate problems together.

questions.definition: How often do you perform changes per system? (Is there a scheduled or adhoc release cycle?)
questions.answer:
Adhoc , work in sprints but not delivering every 2 weeks, patching every 2 or 4 weeks.
When we get the change report from qualys aim to remediate within 2 weeks.

questions.definition:
Do you have a defined set of roles with respect to Change Management procedures?
a.	Do you have a project charter?
b.	How are responsibilities shared?
c.	Do Engineers have the ability to make changes in production?
d.	If so, how is access and privileges managed?
questions.answer: In myservice, when create change ticket we have builder, tester, implementer, business owner. Builder and tester must be different.

questions.definition:
What are your release procedures?
a.	Are they standardised?
b.	Please provide a typical link or CM#
c.	How do you determine a change was successful?
d.	How do you determine that dependant systems are not impacted?
questions.answer:
Once UAT is signed off by the business then create task in myservice for a change ticket for prod ops team to do dry run end to end in UAT ( autosys, batch, rec, config, everything).
After change deployed, tvt technical verification testing testing by Ali's team , confirm implementation plan followed by
bvt business verification testing happens next morning after change and file loaded, 
verify accounts reconciled as expected.
XXXXX Brahma will get link for an example

questions.definition:
What are your rollback procedures?
a.	Are they standardised?
a.	How are these triggered?
questions.answer:
Yes, standardised, delete config and remove changes, remove component added.
No restoration of whole database.

questions.definition:
How do you perform risk analysis and business impact analysis in the change review process?
a.	How many direct upstream and downstream systems do you have?
questions.answer:
Data sets analysed in initial business requirements documents. 
Business impact 2 fold: ask business how critical the rec is, what impacts , regulatory impact if not produced, to generate OLA operation level agreement for loading files , for support team, who to contact e.g. if file not received, whether to raise p2 or p3 or p4 , contains business impact table on how critical file is to complete rec.
In impact tab in myservice write proper assessment of outage and any other systems affected.
26 upstream send files, 1 downstream xcom send file 2.
Pega bank's group case management tool, ticketing system, sends exceptions for technical recs, connects to others systems, team in melbourne investigates.

questions.definition: How do you determine that a change was successful?
questions.answer:
tvt
bvt

questions.definition:
Do you track to any KPIs, metrics, or stats regarding releases (number, frequency of release, duration, people involved, failure/success rate, and other metrics)?
a.	How long does each deployment take?
b.	How long is the associated outage?
c.	How many teams are involved?
questions.answer:
a. How long does each deployment take? 4 hours, config deployment done offshore by TCS bangalore, autosys batch changes by TCS Sydney.
b. How long is the associated outage? no outage.
c. How many teams are involved? usually only 1 team for each change, split into 3 changes.
Big changes may require db team, app support team.
Failure rate less than 10%.   99.99% of changes are successful. may fail because changes mind.

questions.definition: Do you have any targeted and defined improvement goals or based on the above metrics?
questions.answer: Retrospectives in sprints.

questions.definition: After a platform upgrade is there anyway to validate that the upgrade worked and meets the vendors recommended configuration.
questions.answer:
Vendor on network with cba laptop giving oversite.

MK asked about parallel run: not possible, would have to duplicate files, monitoring etc. just do cutover.

questions.definition: Does your team follow CBA's group-wide change management standards?

questions.definition: Can you walk us through your usual change implementation process and steps from inception till production?
questions.answer:
5 step change process.
Logged in myservice ticketing tool.
Changes raised follow normal SDLC assess ... build, test & implementation approvers.
Also tracked in jira with tests cases.
Weekly cab change approval board.
Accurate change every 2 weeks.

questions.definition:
Please describe the type of changes that make up your change pipeline (patching, release, code changes, configuration changes, etc.)
a.	For vendor-provided assets, please describe the process of how new versions of software are received from the vendor.
questions.answer:
App changes: new recs , new matching rules for existing recs to make it more automated, new data feeder or new source to a rec are discussed with business , tested and then go to production.

Scheduling changes outside the application, autosys and batch changes, are not very frequent.
e.g. a new rec will have 3 separate changes 
. rec configuration
. rec source
. batch and autosys scheduling
All 3 implemented on same day ( only thursdays after 8 pm).

Patches goes through same change process ( outside Ali and Brahma's teams)
Changes raised in myservices & documented.
Test plan, cases & strategy in jira.
Signed off & then implemented.

Using SDLC process and testing minimum standard.
Have started using SDLC 2 standard this year (goes up to SDLC 4).

Vendor informs CBA about patches , sending all documentation.

questions.definition: Are you following the same process for all components (e.g. HSM firmware updates and internally developed code)?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.definition:
What type of testing do you perform? (e.g. performance, DR, functional, integration, unit)
a.	Is the level of testing performed varied per change? If so - how is the level of testing determined?
b.	How is this responsibility shared across teams?
questions.answer:
If patching, change will do all testing.
If reconciliation then end to end unit testing to application boundaries.
NFR testing are part of overall test strategy.

How to be sure of capacity?
As part of initial impact assessment, ask what volume is and have to find optimal time slot when can load file and ask when they want it completed by. if team has lots of recs, question will actually need the new rec.

questionnaires.name: Performance
questionnaires.description: The degree to which a service aligns with mandated performance metrics, and the degree to which the performance and efficiency of the service is targeted, tracked and measured.

questions.definition:
What are the performance requirements for the accurate platform (metrics, SLA/SLO)?
Batch processing, viewing reports
questions.answer: All files must be procesed within a day, and finished by 5 pm so that exceptions can be handled

questions.definition: Are there any Customer contractual or industry-wide agreements for Performance? If so, how are these requirements managed?
questions.answer: CBA expected Accurate 219 would be as performant as Accurate 216

questions.definition: How is  performance testing performed on the system?
questions.answer: A day's worth of files are processed with 24 hours. However some environments are much smaller than production, and it is difficult to obtain all files, so  have to extrapolate results to production size. In the 219 upgrad 400 of 600 daily files were processed.

questions.definition:
Which environments are used to run your performance testing (NFT)? Pre-PROD?
a.	How accurately can one extrapolate from these environments to predict production performance?
questions.answer: In staging which is 50% of prodiuction size. Thought that can be extrapolated to prudction size.

questions.definition: How granular are the performance requirements? Do the requirements consider underlying infrastructure? (e.g. HSM response times)?
questions.answer: Nothing

questions.definition: Given the external connectivity for the end-to-end business processes for authorisation how are the differences in the performance of the external parties managed?
questions.answer: No external systems.

questions.definition: How are you reporting performance statistics? Are you running any analysis or/and deriving improvements goals from these statistics?
questions.answer: A spreadsheet is kept manually of job run start and end times, taken from autosys.

questions.definition: Are you keeping track of any performance anomalies and performance related incidents?
How are performance bottlenecks surfaced?
Does the vendor make any promises about performance?
Does the vendor make recommendations to the customer around how to achieve high performance? e.g., infrastructure setup, performant scripts, processing big data.
questions.answer: None.

questions.definition: Who is responsible for performance, customer or vendor?
questions.answer: The vendor verifies that the platform has been setup correctly and it is the customer's responsibility to provide perfomant infrastructure.

questions.definition: How does accurate achieve high performance over large data sets ( matching 100M transactions per day across multiple days)?

questionnaires.name: Security
questionnaires.description: The set of cyber security strategies that prevents unauthorised access to organisational assets including systems, hardware, networks and data.  Maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of sensitive information.  Preventing unauthorised access.

questions.definition: What are the specific roles and groups defined in the team and/or company that are relevant to the Accurate application?
questions.answer:
Privileged roles for infrastructure and application support, 
Standard access for users of the application.
Admins within the privileged roles.

questions.definition:
Are there specific standards or governance frameworks that cover the team's requirements to perform vulnerability scanning, pen testing, and security compliance?
a.	Examples: Cyber Security Non-Negotiables
b.	Maintenance of a Vulnerability Management Programme
c.	Physical access to data centres (if applicable)
d.	Regular Testing
e.	Key ceremonies and register of key custodians
questions.answer:
Vulnerability Management: use qualys
Pen testing: periodically tested anually and after upgrade
PKI key stores - private keys protected within PK stores in app itself with limited access via system. Admins rotate keys
Data at rest: non-needed

questions.definition: Are there any security standards applied by the team governing secure coding best practices, secure communication (encryption in-transit and at rest), authentication, authorisation, and centralised secrets management?
questions.answer:
have best practices and standard operating procedures to harden all systems so out of box configuration doesn't remain , in depth guidelines for general platforms
TLS is used for communication

centralised secrets management: Centralised ID manager

questions.definition:
For cross-system network communications, how are these secured?
a.	Install and maintenance of firewall configuration
b.	Encrypt transmission of data across open public and/or private networks
questions.answer:
uses security zone model 
nothing over public cloud
most communiction encrypted
A few xcom jobs to mainframe not encrypted but doersn't need to be

questions.definition:
How is data secured at rest? 
a.	Management of retention periods and quarterly removal where required.
questions.answer: Not encrypted, does need to be

questions.definition: How are the credentials for users and operators of relevant systems managed?
questions.answer: accurate uses local credentials which are sinked to indentity manger: this is identified as a weakness in the security architecture document.

questions.definition:
How are security issues and breaches surfaced?
a.	Is there any monitoring or recording to alert for suspicious activity?
b.	Track and monitor all access to network resources and data
questions.answer: Using logit to collect logs, logs analysed by flight deck looking for breaches

questions.definition:
Any guidelines and standards followed by the team around network, host or application security scanning?
a.	Develop and maintain secure systems and applications
questions.answer:
regular pen testing 
qualis team looking for known vulnerabilities and patch anomalies

questions.definition:
Is the team collecting any metrics relevant to Security? Are these metrics collated and analysed separately by security experts and asset owners?
a.	Example: No. of unpatched servers over time
b.	Regularly test security systems and processes.
questions.answer: qualys has own metrics and will alert system owner of anomalies, has record of all issues

questions.definition:
What tools and governance procedures enable you to track your security compliance or deviance?
a.	Example: Artefact scanning, static analysis, RiskInSite
questions.answer:
RiskInsight - control gaps and weaknesses 
Pact deviation register -deviation from standards with plan of fixes

questions.definition:
How does the team use group-wide processes and practices governing such risk analysis, shared taxonomy, security rating assessment?
a.	Restrict access to data by business need to know
questions.answer:
internal risk framework OMRF provides templates for risks
Use 5x5 matrix to do assessment of inherent rating; preset patterns/impact; various levels of impact and risk; ratings

questions.definition: What security-related assets are mandated per release - e.g. when reviewing a change record?
questions.answer:
security architecture document at conceptual level
Set of approvals before going to production; security are consulted
security part of standard SDLC and GDF

questionnaires.name: Maintainability
questionnaires.description: The set of attributes that bear on the effort needed to make specified modifications to a system or service.  The ease with which a system or component may be modified to correct faults, improve performance or adapt to a changed environment.  The ease with which a system may be retained in, or restored to a state in which it performs its required functions.

questions.definition: Do you have any documentation or central knowledge repositories where the system modules details and their inter-relationships are defined? Are these documents regularly kept up to date (for instance, when implementing features or performing an upgrade)?
questions.answer:
All docs in documentum and in service management 
https://documents.cba/D2/?docbase=Technology&locateId=0b012952821b9430&commandEvent=D2_ACTION_OPEN_FOLDER&oam_id=0b012952821b9430
https://documents.cba/D2/?docbase=Technology&locateId=0b012952819c5a9d&commandEvent=D2_ACTION_OPEN_FOLDER&oam_id=0b012952819c5a9d

Including 15 Fiserv user guides for various modules.

questions.definition: Who manages the changes to the API specifications (APIs) and their distribution? Who determines which API and standards will be supported? (e.g. OIDC, OAuth2.0)
questions.answer: No API’s, users see their files directly within Accurate.

questions.definition: Does your team maintain and follow standards, guidelines, templates, or playbooks for the development process from requirements to implementation? Are these standards defined group-wide?
questions.answer: Yes, group-wide change management procedures were covered in another session.

questions.definition: Are your functional, non-functional and other requirements stored in a centralised manner?
questions.answer: HLSA stores requirements of Accurate

questions.definition: How granular are the requirement and change specifications? E.g. do they typically get down to the module level?
questions.answer: All change requirements are with originating dept.

questions.definition: How coupled are the modules in your space? Who is responsible for the documentation of the impact of change?
questions.answer: Brahma and the Dev team manage change.

questions.definition: Are you using any data or metrics to track lead time, velocity, cycle time, code coverage, code analysis? Any other metrics such as failed deployment, testing results, escaped defects?
questions.answer: Sprint retrospectives only

questions.definition: Is CBA able to seup non-production environments without a Fiserv sme?
questions.answer: Have tried, web client quite difficult.

questions.definition: Is CBA able to setup a non-production environment with pre-upgrade open cloud infrastructure paired with accurate 219 ?
questions.answer:
Is possible, only start and end are logged.

Supplementary
Q: How long does it take to setup an environment?
2 or 3 days excluding infrastructure.

Q: How easy is it to see what is happening within accurate when a reconciliation is being run? 
Not possible.

Q: What resources are available from Fiserv to help resolve performance issues? 
Have recommended file script changes.
Have run a few things on their laptops.
"We are solo"

Q: Are there any public or private forums where accurate issues and problems can be discussed? 
No.

Q: What testing is done when the platform is upgraded? 
Q: Why do you think this didn't pickup the performance issues?

UAT took 1 month, some users, two full days of data plus specific files, 30 defects 4 or 5 to Fiserv.

file loads took about the same time, 400 of 600 files were loaded in UAT.
Near max processing 22 hours per day, hard to replicate.
Wednesday is worst day , triple the volume
On first wednesday after upgrade, file loading finished at 9pm should have finished at 10 or 11 am.
Large file sequential, small files parallel.
15 to 20 big files of 600 caused 10 hour  delay.
Large file 3 to 4 GB. 
Accurate can only process up to 1 million transactions so have to split large file 6 to 8 GB like CV28GS
degradation in all validation ( of dates in file) , loading and matching.

questionnaires.name: SDLC Process
questionnaires.description: The process used by the organisation to deliver software, including the design, development, testing and packaging of the overall solution to deliver software in a repeatable, methodical way to ensure completion within time and cost estimates.

questions.definition:
What are the primary type of assets developed on the team?
a.	That is - code and software development assets that are authored on your team. This includes management, scripting and deployment infrastructure.
b.	Please call out any major systems & Components (e.g. SSB, SS)
questions.answer:

Supplementary
-------------
Q: where is performance degradation?
Everywhere: loading, matching , database performance poorer, IOPS through roof.
Changes:
accurate is tier 1: active - active to meet availability recoverability requirements
oc3->oc1
sql version
sql availability group synchronous -> asynchronous
os
application - includes rec rules
java

Everything changed except feeders which were uplifted by Fiserv.
Deep analysis has ruled out
a) network traffic ruled out as cause, after deep monitoring
b) virtual disks
c) drives , disk latency
d) disk IOPS through roof at sql end 3,700->15,000 , 216 4k block size increased to 219 264k ( was config problem for 216, didn't cause problem), why sql taking longer when block size increased

CBA has asked fiserv for way to test the number of requests created by accurate but fiserv won't help.

Vendor saying 
a) no change between versions.
b) then minimal change.
c) problem with csv feeder - unicode change in 217 causing 10 to 20% degradation.

Infrastructure has been proven to be good, only other thing is the application.
a) vm ware says disks are fine.
b) network fine latency minimal.

Fiserv insist working fine elsewhere all over the world, and on laptops.
Won't help run similar in staging.
Asked for release notes.

questionnaires.name: Service Continuity
questionnaires.description: The ability to restore services in the event of a disaster (e.g. loss of data centre) that destroys or interrupts service for some or all of the business's resources.  A Business Continuity event, and the processes, procedures and specific actions taken in such event to ensure that service will be restored in a timely manner with no loss of data.

questions.definition:
What is the definition of "disaster" or “business continuity event” in your space?
a.	I.e. is it just 'whole site failure'? Reduced capacity scenarios?
questions.answer:
• Business continuity - can users continue working
• Service continuity - when site goes down
• Disaster - DB has crashed, but can be restored
  a. Reduced capacity scenarios?
Nothing to mind

questions.definition: What are the DR and availability 'primitives' that comprise your system? (e.g. Region – AZ – DC – Rack).
questions.answer: DC - Burwood, Norwest

questions.definition: How often do you rehearse your DR strategy?
questions.answer:
Twice a year
  • First: Burwood site loss
  • Second: Norwest

questions.definition: What steps do you perform in a DR situation? Are the steps documented in a group-wide tool (e.g. Rufus)?
questions.answer: All documented in Rufus

questions.definition: How long does it take to perform every step in the plan?
questions.answer:
Old solution - couple of hours : 2.16 on OC3
New solution - yet to be tested : 2.19 on OC1

questions.definition: Is there any formalised segmentation performed on upstream systems/customers?
questions.answer: None at all

questionnaires.name: Incident Management
questionnaires.description: The tooling and processes enabling an appropriate response to incidents and the alignment with broader incident management frameworks throughout the organisation.

questions.definition: What are the major P1/P2 incidents that happened over the last 6 months?
questions.answer:
p2 346348 for upgrade performance closed and replaced by problem ticket
p2 database locking
p2 files not received

questions.definition: What were the nature of the incidents / which systems have been impacted? Any general themes? (e.g. networking, hardware, software)?
questions.answer:
p2 database locking
p2 files not received

questions.definition: What are your monitoring and alerting tools / processes?
questions.answer:
databases:
a) com? monitoring
b) name forgotten
Splunk monitoring of all ssis jobs, creates automated incidents.
autosys jobs creates automated incidents.

questions.definition: How are you accessing production? Are you using a jump-box, TPAM, one‐time password?
questions.answer:
Ops team can use jump host.
Jump host for application thick client.
Jump host gateway for accurate.

questions.definition: Do you have audits of all production activity?
questions.answer:
All users have named accounts.
All activity audited.
Users access level reviewed monthly or quarterly.
A sample of incidents are audited.

questions.definition: Are you aware of all business and/or system specific SLAs/SLOs while fixing production issues?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.definition: Do you have any incident runbook and knowledge-base repositories to refer to in case of incident?
questions.answer:
Use standard incident management with operational guide or sop for known issues and standard procedures to address root cause.
Don't have knowledge-base in ops.
There is knowledge management for service desk to follow to assist users.

questions.definition: What is your on‐duty call process?
questions.answer:
Coverage 6am to 10 pm.
Batch team monitors batches overnight.
p2 supported 24 by 7.

questions.definition: What are the communication channels and methods during an incident?
questions.answer:
Bulletin notification tool.
Email myservice (tool for call logging , incident management, problem management, change management, service requests) 
to reassign incidents if failure not in Accurate.

questions.definition: Do you have any specific approach to problem analysis during an incident?
questions.answer:
Track corrective actions.
Root cause identification. 
Permanent corrective action.
Through myservice.

questions.definition: Do you use any tools in particular to pinpoint the root cause of issues? (e.g. Splunk, AppDynamics…)
questions.answer:
Do have appdynamics but used lightly.
Splunk logit collects logs.
Flight deck raises incidents from the logs.


scom alerting monitoring and support provided for all services

questions.definition: Do you hold Incident Retrospective (PIR, Post‐incident review) meetings? How frequently?
questions.answer: No

questions.definition: Are you rehearsing regularly the processes and resolution steps of past incidents?
questions.answer: Identified with p2 for upgrade that aren't recording actions taken to restore the service.

questions.definition: Are you gathering any specific health metrics (volume, severity of incidents, number of escalations)?
questions.answer: Volume of incidents: yes, reviewed by TCS service delivery managers at a high level

questions.definition: Are any advanced metrics gathered such as MTTD, MTTR, number of escalations?
questions.answer:
Part of tcs reporting.  
XXXX follow up with JY

questions.definition: Are you reporting/reflecting on existing metrics to spot any trends/patterns?
questions.answer:
Not effectively.
Daily ops review all open incidents. 
Looked at from monthly reporting.

questions.definition: Are you consistently determining the cost per previous incidents?
questions.answer:
No

Supplementary questions
=======================
Q: Why didn't they upgrade to 2.17 ? 
They didn't know.
Q: Is accurate chatty with db? 
216 and 219 both make many db calls, because process blocks of 100.
Q: can they see the sql being run?
Yes, long running sql statements can be seen in sql console. application doesn't log any details of what happening, only start and finish.
Q: can that sql be run in console with explain?
DBA have done this , looked at indexes, script takes < 3 minutes while jobs takes a long time, the implication being that the matching is taking place in the application server.
Apparently java code in jboss is not being used.

questionnaires.name: Auditability
questionnaires.description: The ability of a system to generate or obtain required artifacts to provide assurance that the system is safe, data integrity is maintained and the system is operating effectively. Compliance with all requirements including standards, policies, laws and service level agreements (SLA)

questions.definition: Are there any audit reports that are generated and reviewed on a regular basis ?
questions.answer:
We we've got different types of audit from. It's either internal audit or whether it's a PwC audit or whether it's a system ordered.

There are two things here. First one, which is looked after by the business user is there are some audit reports which can be generated as regarding the Rex or the account switch. The reconciliations as done right? So those reports can be generated from the system. Those are the reports. Also there are. We have some SSIS jobs which extracts the report.
It's not a audit report, but it's actually provides a report. How much data has reconciled.
OK so so not on the system we have got anything. Only thing is like we have got changed management change process. So in terms of anything happening on the system any changes going in everything will be logged in under change and even if any incidents happen, any activity done on the systems by the operation subscript support team, they go and update the ticket incident related to that.

questions.definition: What are the tools used to generate the audit reports ?
questions.answer:
it's myservice.
Any changes or any incident fixes or breaks up recording any breaks, so that's our pretty much our audit if we want it to look back at a certain period of time when what has changed to accurate.

questions.definition: What are the manual audits that you perform ?
questions.answer:
Uh, performance. We reporting the same. How what changes has been? How many changes for an application for the month of or for the quarter over the last six months, changes, incident problems and service request?
So more of a how the system is.

Uhm, performing the majority of it? Where's? Where's all the problems or incidents generating from the? You know, the top polluter or which component of a an application is causing a lot of the incidents.

I don't know whether you can call that as an audit, but more of a review of the plot of the service.

questions.definition: What are the human reviews performed ? What are the events that you review ?
questions.answer: tba

questions.definition: What are the critical events, and how are they monitored ?
questions.answer:
Whether it's a we we have to go through the classifying it or categorizing it based on their their impact and urgency.
So that would be P1P2P3 and P4 hours. So if there's a business impact, the business impact is great. Then it needs to be justified in the we need to address that through the high priority incident.
You know, if you if you just say a file hasn't arrived from into accurate that we're expecting it at at 6:00 o'clock in the morning.
But that actual file is critical to.
The business then that's already pre agreed to saying that that stream of that stream is treated as a P2 and then we go through the incident.
Process to elevate that to a high priority incident and then treat it and resolve it within the four hour with.

questions.definition: Are there any known vulnerabilities in the current auditing system ?
questions.answer: tba

questions.definition: Are there logs captured for the platform ?
questions.answer:
Yeah, so application logs are like a separate then the system log like server logs are captured in the Windows event viewer.
All of those logs are separate than the application logs after the amount of log which we have is not helping us to identify the like what the background process is happening. But like we have got application logs separately.

questions.definition: What are the different logs captured ?
questions.answer:
There are the system logs captured on the server.
And some are stored in Splunk.

questions.definition: Where are the logs captured ?
questions.answer: And some are stored in Splunk.

questions.definition: How long does it take for the logs to appear on the log capturing tool ?
questions.answer: So the long feature captured in log ITR Splunk. That is like we can see immediate. It's like the last five minutes long we can see it and like I'm something is getting written on the server on the server logs that's gets moved to the Splunk in like in a minute I can just query now and I can get the latest results there.

questions.definition: Is infrastructure capacity monitored ? If so, how ?
questions.answer: It is monitored by SCOM. For any for the CPU, memory, heartbeat, disks and all that, so that's that's part of the service

questions.definition: Are there dashboards created to monitor critical events ?
questions.answer: So that's centralized to the flight deck, so they look after those types of learning and critical events. And if something is done operations and platform OPS will be notified of a system being heartbeat failure or capacity at.

Process to elevate that to a high priority incident and then treat it and resolve it within the four hour with.

questions.definition: Are there any known vulnerabilities in the current auditing system ?
questions.answer: tba

questions.definition: Are there logs captured for the platform ?
questions.answer:
Yeah, so application logs are like a separate then the system log like server logs are captured in the Windows event viewer.
All of those logs are separate than the application logs after the amount of log which we have is not helping us to identify the like what the background process is happening. But like we have got application logs separately.

questions.definition: What are the different logs captured ?
questions.answer:
There are the system logs captured on the server.
And some are stored in Splunk.

questions.definition: Where are the logs captured ?
questions.answer: And some are stored in Splunk.

questions.definition: How long does it take for the logs to appear on the log capturing tool ?
questions.answer: So the long feature captured in log ITR Splunk. That is like we can see immediate. It's like the last five minutes long we can see it and like I'm something is getting written on the server on the server logs that's gets moved to the Splunk in like in a minute I can just query now and I can get the latest results there.

questions.definition: Is infrastructure capacity monitored ? If so, how ?
questions.answer: It is monitored by SCOM. For any for the CPU, memory, heartbeat, disks and all that, so that's that's part of the service

questions.definition: Are there dashboards created to monitor critical events ?
questions.answer: So that's centralized to the flight deck, so they look after those types of learning and critical events. And if something is done operations and platform OPS will be notified of a system being heartbeat failure or capacity at.

questionnaires.name: Vendor Aggreements
questionnaires.description: Vendor standard contract templates developed and being used; Contract SLAs being actively managed and monitored; Capability improvement is built into the vendor management model; Contract cost being evaluated against business value.

questions.definition: Is there an agreement with the vendors for Accurate ? If so how many vendors ?
questions.answer:
1:1 Fiserv software license , gives software and license keys to use on CBA network, vendor has no hold on data. for 4 environments Dev, UAT, Stg, Prod (Dev and UAT as many environments as want, only 1 for prod).
fee based on number of users
58 user licenses view exceptions to manually match and run reports provided by vendor, 20%.

users login to gui to view exceptions, can manually match unmatched , and can run standard reports

questions.definition: What sub agreement exists ?
questions.answer: Fiserv PSA which cover the 2.16 to 219 upgrade with 6 Milestones, all cash incentivized to A$398K, with a Fiserv 192 step upgrade run book approach.

questions.definition: Where does the contract sit? Is it with an Individual ?
questions.answer:
ES finance portfolio.
Contract sent to Nidhi, Ali , Vivek (Prashant's manager)
Paid by Nidhi and Scott GM in consulation with Vivek

questions.definition:
What is the agreement with each vendor?
A) Is there a lockin period?
B) Any extensions to the existing contract?
questions.answer:
Yearly license fee, with 2.19 upgrade lockin for 3 years with cooling off period.
Previously on 2.16 was year by year.
License fee 20% of original cost adjusted for inflation.

questions.definition: How is a service built ? What is the techology used?
questions.answer:
No longer delivered by CD as per release.
It is an appliance.
Built in hybrid languages C++ C# with backed sql (Sybase, Oracle, SQL Server).
For patches, the vendor sends patch and manual which is tested in lower environment then deployed to change, 
vendor has support team in india.
For upgrades, the vendor is engaged as CBA employee, he had access to environments and with Brahma and Ali completes the install. 
Fiserv upgraded backend database.
Instructions mention delivery by cd but not true, downloaded from web site.
Confirmed, Accurate is an appliance: hard to see what is going on inside.

questions.definition: Could you please share the contract?
questions.answer:
Prashant emailed contact and contracts.
2 contracts for original purchase and for upgrade.
Original purchase was in 2009. 
Ali thru 3 upgrades 2012, 2013, 2016 & 2019.
CBA doesn't upgrade every time or immediately, always 2 or 3 versions behind.
Last upgrade was 1m, complex to do in big organisation.

questions.definition: Is there areas in the contract that are lacking?
questions.answer:
Original contract needs to be reviewed but isn't.
Eficiency: need active engagement with Fiserv product team to test new builds and guide development, definitely part of beta testing, poor from them.
bau support is good
upgrade support is good

questions.definition: How is legal and procurement managed? Is it centralized?
questions.answer: Centraised procurement team EPP in CBA, not easy to sign contract with Fiserv.

questions.definition: How is dispute resolution managed in the contract?
questions.answer:
if variation needed in contract then talk to account manager in Oz, Ian Welland.
Some minor adjustments have been done.
Not many , not major contract issues.

questions.definition: Does the contract mention SLA's and performance related requirement?
questions.answer:
No SLAs or performance requirements.
Fiserv give CBA the software and its a blackbox. 
They specify how it should be deployed and configured e.g Ram, disk space, performance is up to CBA. analogy with excel macro.    
Outside of contract Fiserv provide recommended configurations etc (installation instructions) 
and CBA share infrastructure design with Fiserv who validate it.

questions.definition: Does the contract define penalties? If so what are they ?
questions.answer:
Will be penalties for unlicensed use, audited every year.
No penalties pertaining to performance of recs.

questions.definition: Is this standardised template or vendor provided template?
questions.answer:
It is a Fiserv contract.
CBA reads or gets changes if necessary.

questions.definition: How are the contract SLAs managed? Any regular reviews done?
questions.answer:
Support SLAs: respond within a day.
Fiserv responds timely.
SLA's not being reviewed.
Support not being used much ( 5 or 6 times a year).
CBA knows software well.
CBA must certify customised scripts, 
People must be certified to create scripts, must be registered to be able to use them, scripts must be check-summed 
by them ( 10 to 15 on a typical day ).
Currently no one at CBA is certified.

questions.definition: Are there any risks identified?
questions.answer:
Risks on security patching - patch in Jan.
Ldap is not encrypted.

questions.definition: Does the client provide thought leadership actively?
questions.answer:
Fiserv do not actively seek feedback, do showcase new software if CBA asks for it.

Supplementary
-----
Q: how wedded to Fiserv?
In 2009 Fiserv was first product available in Australia.
Now very wedded.
Open to other products, have had demos of other prods.
Ali has 8 years experience of Accurate.
Accounting, Bank rec leader.
Other products good for AI , Accurate 20 years behind.
1990s software.
We were told that Fiserv would not discuss doing an incremental upgrade - 
18 months ago when upgrade started, told to go to 2.19.  version 3 is available but a mess and withdrawn.
Fiserv only support 2.18 and 2.19, not much difference between 2.18 and 2.19.
Costs and disruption to bau, Fiserv release once every 12 or 18 months.
Q: any trouble getting an SME ?
Not getting access to product team SME at 2 levels, technical consultants come and upgrade, 
product SME sits in US and does not respond.
