stakeholders.role: Project Manager, FS IT Portfolio Mngt

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* Accurate (v2.16 & v2.19) has an **ARC tier rating of 1** with availability of 99.99%, as of December 2016 (*refer to section Appendix 6.3.*).
* Accurate has no direct integration with any upstream or downstream systems, availability issues have no direct impact to any upstream or downstream systems.
* Failover is manual, with active-passive setup across two datacentres, Burwood & Norwest.
* Platform availability is dependent on the manual disaster recovery process, which incurs downtime to restore services. 99.99% and/or 24/7 uptime cannot be guaranteed
* Database availability and recoverability differs between both instances, with v2.16 using database mirroring, while v2.19 uses SQL Server Availability Groups, with asynchronous replication.
* All outages trigger incidents to FlightDeck and Application Support and Operations teams.
* Availability Reports in Service Management are collected on a monthly and/or quarterly basis.
* Availability and Capacity data captured by SCOM agents on servers and stored in LogIT. Data collected is being used for monitoring and reporting purposes. This data is not actively correlated with other metrics to proactively manage the platform to perform any pre-emptive remediation.
* Little to no availability testing at a granular level of multiple failure scenarios in non-production environments.
* TCS performs testing as defined below though interviews confirm that no comparison is taking place between results and ARC tier requirements.
  * SCAT testing taking place annually
  * MERT testing is taking place on a biannual basis, collection of results does not undergo review resulting in system improvement
  * Service continuity testing is taking place twice a year.
  * Security testing is being applied as requested by CBA IT Security recommendations.
* TCS retains a measure of SLAs and SLOs however they make no comparison with CBA app target SLAs and SLOs
* Business continuity tests are performed bi-annually at data centre level. All upstream stream and downstream applications take part in this failover simulation.
* Disaster recovery is taking place at a platform level however no evidence exists of it taking place at a business function level.
recommendations.risk:
* Environments, systems, and dependent components have varying probabilities of failure, and the limited discoverability via group tooling of such potential failures and their cascading impacts may result in the inability of the organisation to accurately risk assess change and mitigate risks to the Accurate Platform.
* Neglect in comparing availability results with SLOs and SLAs established for the system would indicate that no tangible goals exist.
* Availability Test Report is not portraying an accurate depiction of uptime, this conceals underlying outages and prevents them being addressed methodically.
* Absence of granular availability testing, mean production availability cannot be guaranteed in the event of specific failures, e.g., app, web, database, network, or dependent components.
* Lack of automation impacts the teams? ability to repeatably and consistently assure uptime. This may result in longer availability testing cycles and inconsistencies in results, thereby impacting the overall platform availability.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Conduct regular reviews of SLAs/SLOs.** Conduct regular reviews to compare SLOs and SLAs to application performance targets.
* **Comprehensive automated availability testing.** More comprehensive availability and failover testing in non-production environments must be set up. It should be possible to test multiple failure scenarios in a non-production setting, in an environment that is equivalent to production. Ideally, this would use scripting and automation tooling.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* Accurate change management process is controlled by overarching policy. The process is not tailored to Accurate though permits for controlled methodology for introducing changes to a stable production environment.
* All interviews would indicate that staff are following the process that has been regulated through the Group Policy, this is captured by MyService entry records.
* TCS does not appear to have established metrics surrounding the change management process. The v2.16 environment has not been baselined to compare against the uplifted v2.19 environment. Upgrades to the infrastructure and new configuration cannot be accurately verified to be delivering improved performance.
* Change management appears to all be taking place manually with minimal to no automation in use.
* CBA IT Architecture practice has approved a major infrastructure uplift and redesign for the v2.19 instance (*.**., SQL Server Availability Groups*), however the benefits have not been confirmed through testing.
* Accurate software release cycle has not been followed, with two releases been skipped to avoid business interruption, attributed to complexity, time, and cost.
* Production approval for platform upgrades and patching is not contingent on successful outcome of comprehensive testing, e.g., unit, load, performance, and regression.
* Only a subset of accounts and files are tested prior to production release ? Not all the 300-400 accounts and 600 files have been tested.
  * Staff interviews indicate that resourcing; time constraints; complexity in obtaining and sanitising production data all played a role.
  * Potential issues related to file size and transaction volumes may have been undetected.
* Rollback procedure is to remove changes and components. However, the database is NOT restored during the rollback procedure.
* Deployments into Production take approximately 4 hours.
* Deployments of configuration changes are handled offshore by TCS in Bangalore.
* Autosys and Batch changes are handled by TCS in Sydney.
* 99.99% of implemented Production changes are successful.
recommendations.risk:
* Absence of detailed metrics surrounding the change management process removes opportunities for trend analysis, improvement requires trend analysis.
* Partial testing meant potential issues related to file size and transaction volume may have been undetected, resulting in performance issues only manifesting in production.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Production releases should be contingent on successful testing**. Future production releases should be gated or contingent on a successful outcome of a comprehensive test approach, which should include the latest copy of all sanitized production files and database. This should be run in a pre-production environment that exactly mirrors production.
* **Introduce metrics to enable trends analysis.** Introduce metrics to enable trends analysis .., Time to Release, Failure/Success Rate, Number of manual stages per release. 
* **Automate the change management**. Automate the change management process to avoid inadvertent errors.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* Standard incident management is used with an operational guide for known issues and standard procedures are used to address the root cause. Root cause analysis tools include AppDynamics, Splunk logit and FlightDeck. * The Accurate platform teams follow CBA?s incident management processes and use the organisation?s incident management tools. * Communication channels and methods used during incidents include the bulletin notification tool to inform users, email, and MyService. * Incident retrospectives are not held to review and document the solution * Incidents are reviewed monthly by TCS service delivery managers at a high level. * No trends analysis taking place for production incidents, particularly surrounding cost, and opportunity. * Automated incident reporting & monitoring in place for ETL and Autosys batch jobs. * The on?duty call process coverage is between 6am to 10 pm. * The Batch team monitors batches overnight. * P2 incidents are supported 24x7, P3 incidents are supported during business hours. * Major P2 incidents occurring in the last twelve months:
Incident IDOpen TimeDescription
IM35700651/12/2021 5:20Accurate: Long running sessions causing blocking in load and autorec process
IM321950321/03/2021 13:17Accurate Indexing job has failed
IM318458619/02/2021 3:58Accurate Fin-ops: Not able to connect to Database/Application not accessible.
IM346342826/10/2021 12:16Accurate application job running longer - Severe Performance Degradation
recommendations.risk:
* The lack of real-time metrics and correlation with formalised SLAs and SLOs may decrease visibility of issues in the Accurate platform.
* Lack of trends analysis to identify potential issues, could result in a gradual degradation in performance without a clear path to improvement.
* Absence of Assurance protocol for incident management could result in reoccurrence of errors that were thought to have been corrected and closed.
* The absence of CBA technical review for incidents, could be indicative of process improvement failure. The incident is rectified, though the root cause is not clear and hence likely to recur.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Conduct incident trend analysis**. Leverage incident data and metrics for incidents to analyse trends, which should cover operational cost and component failure as a minimum to ensure the efficiency of the system is maintained or improved.
* **Collect and use advanced detailed metrics.** Collect advanced detailed metrics and use in real-time to improve incident response and proactively identify potential failures .., file sizes, transaction volumes, long running database queries, network traffic, memory, and CPU spikes. 
* **Update SOPs and SMPs regularly.** SOPs and SMPs need to be updated regularly to reflect the current state of the system.

recommendations.title: Responsibilities for Maintenance and Upgrades
recommendations.observation:
* Accurate is a software system owned by Fiserv, that is leased in a typical proprietary software leasing arrangement to CBA under a three-year agreement subject to renewal (*refer to section 5.10 Vendor Agreements*).
* Maintenance issues specific to the Accurate software are undertaken by Fiserv with support services offered to CBA to aid the improvement of system performance. Support services offered include:
  * Installation instructions
  * Infrastructure options
  * Recommends scaling approaches
  * Authorises load scripts to be run by inserting a check sum into vendor scripts
  * SME to aid upgrades and signoff
* All system infrastructure is owned by CBA, CBA is responsible for:
  * Chooses which infrastructure options to deploy
  * Performance and support of infrastructure
  * Testing of Fiserv installed upgrades
  * Security etc.
* Staff interviews indicate that there is a major release of Accurate every eighteen months, and the upgrades are manual, complex, costly, time consuming and disrupt BAU significantly as development of new reconciliations must be halted. As a result, CBA has opted to skip some upgrades.
* Except for vendor support, there is an absence of other support channels to assist users addressing issues, e.g., community forums.
* Documentation of Accurate is limited, Fiserv expects developers to undertake a certification course to be able to perform script development.
* Performance and load testing in pre-production environment is the responsibility of CBA, with no validation required from Fiserv (?*UAT, SIT, and performance and security testing shall be performed by the Client. Fiserv shall only provide testing support, and support during the UAT*?.
* Basic metrics are being collected mainly from Autosys to generate reports, with insufficient detail to assist teams to proactively manage and support the platform.
recommendations.risk:
* As software ownership is separate from infrastructure it creates problems that CBA is unable to detect and correct to satisfy their performance targets.
* Skipped upgrades have proven costly in hindsight and introduced unwanted problems, these could lead to larger outages in time.
* The absence of detail metrics covering the entire platform and its components, make it difficult for teams to proactively identify areas of concern and their ability to remediate.
recommendations.recommendation: * **Collect metrics of the ecosystem holistically to enhance the maintainability.** Metrics that could be collected include file size, numbers of successful reconciliations, times, durations of user queries, and configuration settings like block size and the size large files are split into.

recommendations.title: Failed Upgrades and EOL
recommendations.observation:
* At present there are two version of the system in use: Accurate v.2.19 and Accurate v.2.16. * The v.2.19 instance is unable to process all files within 24 hours as required by the NFR for the system (refer *to section 5.5 Performance).* * The v.2.16 instance has not been decommissioned and **processing is shared between the v2.16 and v2.19 instances**, this has been done to bring the processing time for reconciliations under 24hrs. It is unclear at this point who was responsible for this decision, though it was applied as a mitigation measure for a failing upgrade. * Version v2.16 of Accurate is no longer supported by Fiserv and requires upgrade. Staff interviews indicate that the infrastructure on which v2.16 runs, is reaching end-of-life and must also be upgraded, the OS and DB are already out of support. See table below for further details:
AccurateMicrosoftMainstream SupportExtended Support
v2.16MS Windows Server 2012
(See Product Lifecycle)Oct 92018Oct 10
MS SQL Server 2012
(See Product Lifecycle)Jul 112017Jul 12
v2.19Windows Server 2016
(See Product Lifecycle)Jan 112022Jan 12
Microsoft SQL Server 2016
(See Product Lifecycle)Jul 132021Jul 14
* Staff interviews indicate that CBA asked Fiserv to undertake upgrades between v2.16 and v2.19 (i.e., 2.17, 2.18, and v2.19). Fiserv refused to provide CBA with incremental upgrades and provided a single upgrade that combined the changes in 2.17, 2.18 and v2.19 into a single upgrade. * Upgrade testing did not highlight any performance issues that manifested when CBA moved production loads to the upgraded platform (*refer to section 5.9 Testability*).
recommendations.risk:
* Running two versions of Accurate increases operational complexity and increases the risk of failures, doubling the operational workload.
* If the unsupported v2.16 instance fails for any reason, there is a risk that issues will may not be resolved quickly by CBA, which will disrupt business.
* Because v2.16 is using unsupported versions of the OS and DB which will not have the latest patches, there is an increased security risk.
* Accurate is an old technology stack which will become increasing difficult to support at CBA and to maintain by Fiserv.
* Add automated unit, performance, and load testing. This is detailed in the Testability section. It will enhance maintainability by making upgrades much easier, faster, and more reliable.
* Maintaining a regular cycle with patches and upgrades. Upgrades will be less disruptive if testing is automated.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Keep software up to date**. The Accurate platform and its supporting software and components should be kept up to date with the latest upgrades and patches. Strict adherence to vendor software release cycles is necessary.
* **Automate the upgrade process.** There are five environments per Accurate version, with a single instance each, and it has been proposed run two instances in production. Automation would make upgrades faster, reliable, repeatable.

recommendations.title: Scalability
recommendations.observation:
* v2.16 is running 22/24 hours per day and cannot cope with expected volume increases as defined in the NFRs of the HLSA.
* Fiserv has recommended running two instances of Accurate v2.19 to handle the expected volumes, as documented in the HLSA. However, this has not been implemented.
* Fiserv has suggested two possible approaches to scale Accurate:
  * Vertical scaling: with increased capacity components.
  * Horizontal scaling: with multiple v2.19 instances.
recommendations.risk:
* Because load testing has failed to detect the root cause of current performance issues, these will persist with platform in its current state.
* Unless the platform scaled up, there is a risk the platform will not be able to process expected increase in volumes, ultimately leading to service failure of one or more components.
recommendations.recommendation: * **Consider scaling options to increase availability and capacity**. Consider horizontal scaling of with an additional v2.19 instance to distribute the workload and mitigate any performance issues thereby allowing the decommissioning of v2.16. Alternatively, consider vertical scaling by increasing compute and infrastructure capacity on the v2.19 instance, to allow higher throughput.

recommendations.title: Performance Issues
recommendations.observation:
* Non-functional requirements related to performance specified in the HLSA include:
  * *NFR 6 for Scalability states:* ?The solution must support increase of 40% of data volumes per year?. 
  * *NFR 4 for Performance states:* ?User Experience when files are loading into Accurate should not be affected?.
  * *NFR 3 for Capacity states:* The system must be able to ?Load 100 million transaction per day?.
* In both versions of the Accurate, database records must be regularly archived to prevent performance degradation.
* Staff interviews indicate that processing of a day of transactions in the v2.16 instance pre-upgrade took 20 to 22 hours, which is close to the daily limit. Maximum weekly load is on Wednesdays, with triple the normal volume, and seasonal variations occur during the year, i.e., pre-Christmas.
* Limited testing of the upgraded v2.19 instance did not detect performance problems that eventuated when production loads were switched to the new v2.19 instance (refer *to section 5.9 Testability* for a discussion of upgrade testing and related issues).
* Staff interviews indicate that the 15 to 20 biggest files caused 10 hours delay to overall processing on the upgraded v2.19 instance. Consequently, it is unable to process all files within 24 hours. As an interim measure to mitigate this, the v2.16 platform has not been decommissioned and processing is partitioned between the two instances as follows:
  * v2.16 ? runs high volume technical reconciliations which do not require roll forward of opening balances
  * v2.19 ? runs financial reconciliations which require roll forward of closing balances
* Staff interviews indicate that the only metrics available in Accurate are the times and durations of the reconciliation jobs, as evidenced in the Autosys Job Timings extract*,* supplied by Operations (*refer to Appendix 6.3.2*). There are no metrics about facets of the processing or platform that influence performance, such as files sizes, transaction numbers, errors, numbers of transactions automatically reconciled, total database size, and queries being run by end users when managing exceptions.
* Interviews with CBA have noted that the infrastructure has been checked and has been shown to be performing well.
* Interviews with CBA indicate that performance database queries being run in a reconciliation job have been investigated by a CBA DBA. Findings indicate that database queries take less than 3 minutes to execute while the matching process in the Accurate Batch Server, is taking significantly longer.
recommendations.risk:
* If the v2.16 instance cannot be decommissioned, there is increased operational risk as that version is unsupported by Fiserv. Additionally, the supporting OS and DB are out of support.
* Unless performance problems in v2.19 are resolved or mitigated, CBA may have to run multiple instances of the platform which leads to increased operation complexity and risk (*refer to section 5.4 Maintainability for details of possible mitigations).* 
* Unless performance problems in v2.19 are resolved or mitigated, further increases in transaction volume will result in processing delays, with the platform running out of capacity and potentially platform failure.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Detect potential issues with performance testing.** Comprehensive performance and load testing should be conducted in pre-production environments to simulate production activity. Record baseline performance in v2.16 instance against the v2.19 instance on the same infrastructure and workloads. Rerun performance tests consistently using the same data; introducing any changes incrementally .., varying the split size, block size, and database size.
* **Collect additional metrics to help understand application performance.** Additional metrics will help explain performance variations caused by variations in inputs, configuration, and concurrent processing for instance (*refer to section 5.4 Maintainability*). .., file sizes, transaction volumes, long running database queries, network traffic, memory, and CPU spikes.

recommendations.title: Vendor Engagement
recommendations.observation:
* As an interim measure, to partially mitigate the performance issues in the v2.19 instance, Fiserv made some performance improvements to the Feeder scripts generated by the Accurate client application, to speed up file loading for large files.
* Interviews with the Fiserv SME suggest that the CBA infrastructure may potentially be the cause of the performance issues.
* Staff interviews indicate that Fiserv initially stated that there were no changes between version v2.16 and v2.19 that may have caused the performance degradation seen at the Bank, however subsequently admitted that a Unicode change in the CSV Feeder in v2.17 causes a 10 to 20% performance degradation. However, this does not account for all the performance degradation seen.
* In an interview, Fiserv SMEs could not provide any details of how reconciliation processing works, which may help establish the root cause.
* Fiserv SMEs did not provide any advice or expertise on how CBA could resolve the performance issues or configure the infrastructure.
* In an interview, Fiserv have noted that they have 50-60 clients worldwide using Accurate v2.19, none of which have performance issues. With at least one client running a similar configuration to CBA, i.e., clustered databases.
recommendations.risk:
* Lack of available resources and willingness from vendor to engage with CBA to resolve issues, means issues may persist and degrade further over time.
* Lack of system ownership can result in problems lingering in an unresolved state causing larger outages.
recommendations.recommendation: * **Request vendor resources to assist with resolution**: Engage with Fiserv to deploy Accurate SMEs on site to work alongside CBA resources to identify and resolve issues. The goal is to solve the stalemate in progress.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* Staff interviews indicate that development is split across two teams:
  * The Accurate Development Team automate backend jobs that load data scheduled through Autosys.
  * The Finance Business Team build matching logic, taking requirements from business, setup the matching and building the views the front user sees. They deliver the reconciliation end-to-end.
* Design and development of reconciliations is performed using Accurate tools:
  * Matching rules are generated using the *Accurate Client Application* GUI.
  * Feeder shell scripts are generated by the *Accurate Driver Generator* tool which CBA extends then Fiserv validates
  * All testing is manual, with little to no automation or use of testing frameworks
* Staff interviews indicate that five artifacts are created per reconciliation, excluding the matching rules which are not an artifact per se as they are managed by the tool
  * Autosys configuration
  * Batch file
  * Folder creation
  * Feeder scripts
  * SQL reporting through SSIS package, including queries and stored procedures for customised reports
* Staff interviews indicate that two to three hundred reconciliations exist, and these do not change often, with one to three reconciliations are being usually developed per week.
* Staff interviews indicate that after the failed v2.19 upgrade, development cannot occur in the upgraded instance and cannot be reverted to the v2.16 instance as it is out of support.
* Staff interviews indicate that after performance issues were detected in the upgraded v2.19 instance, attempts were made to reconfigure production infrastructure to fix the issues, but an accurate record of the changes was not kept.
recommendations.risk:
* Configuring Accurate environments manually is inherently less reliable than automation.
* Not having a record of corrective actions taken to fix the upgrade brings into question the validity of the corrective actions applied.
* Having environments with different and unknown configurations invalidates those environments and makes development and testing less reliable.
* Applying changes directly in production with validating in pre-production risks leaving the platform in an unstable state and will directly impact business and potentially result in downtime to rectify.
* Not having automated testing, introduces human error making development, testing and upgrades less reliable and less consistent.
* Not automating the upgrade process makes upgrades less reliable and less efficient.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **A record of all manual configuration changes must be kept.** This must be done if changes are made manually, to understand what affect those changes have had and to apply them identically to all environments.
* **Use a configuration management tool to apply configuration**. Configuration management tools apply configuration reliably, log changes and prevent configuration drift caused by manual changes. 
* **Automate the upgrade process.** There are five environments per Accurate version, with a single instance each, and it has been proposed run two instances in production. Automation would make upgrades faster, reliable, repeatable.
* **Rebuild the production environment in the v2.19 instance so that it has a known state**. Unrecorded changes were made to fix the performance issues in the upgraded instance. It must be configured the same as the other environments.
* **Test infrastructure and configuration changes in pre-production**. Run performance and load tests on each change and apply to production only if the change is successful (*refer to section 5.9 Testability on testing recommendations*).
* **Automate all testing**. This will make the SDLC process more consistent and reliable. This could leverage CI/CD and automation to minimise human error. Recommendations related to testing are covered in section *5.9 Testability*.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* Accurate is deployed on an internal private cloud which uses a security zone model divided into three security zones and has a security classification of Medium (C) as defined in the *Security Architecture document*. 
* Accurate uses local accounts, which are not integrated or synchronised with the Bank?s Active Directory and Identity management.
* There are standard access roles and groups for users of the application and privileged roles and groups for infrastructure and application support.
* Privileged management users access servers through a jump host.
* Qualys is used for vulnerability management and patch anomalies.
* Analytics are used to pick out issues but there are no eyes on glass looking for security issues as the volumes of data are large.
* Logs are collected in real-time from Accurate servers and sent to Logit, where they are scanned for events of interest.
* Penetration testing team decide if a Penetration test is needed, only when there are significant upgrades.
* Accurate uses CBA?s past deviation register to record deviations from standards so that issues are resurfaced to ensure that plans are created to solve the deviations.
* Accurate databases in the v2.19 instance use SQL Server mixed mode authentication, which rely on local database accounts.
* Insecure LDAP is being used by Accurate thick client to access the Application.
* Thick client connections to Accurate databases from dedicated jump hosts and Accurate application uses the insecure LDAP protocol.
recommendations.risk:
* Use of local accounts result in ineffective centralised control which can lead to potential gaps when off-boarding users due to lack of real-time synchronisation with centralised identity management.
* There is a potential risk of?privilege abuse or system compromise when there is no standard life cycle which?include owner approval, password rotation/resets and account deletions along with associated Governance controls a centralised Identity Manager provide.
* Any compromise of Accurate credentials could potentially result in unauthorised access to General Ledger summaries, Project costs, purchase orders and other various financial data, resulting in possible legal and compliance issues leading to fines and sanctions as well as damage to brand reputation.
* With the use of insecure LDAP, the potential exists for the ability to sniff the LDAP credentials by internal actors with privileged access to connecting systems or internal network devices.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Centralize account governance to prevent credentials being compromised in future.** Requests for all new local accounts to register on IDAM with necessary Service owner approvals. Externalise Privilege accounts to Bank's PAM solution and mechanisms. Conduct regular User Access Review of Privileged accounts (.., every 6-12 months). Ensure adherence to Bank password policy. 
* **Use secure authentication mechanisms**. Use LDAPS or other secure protocol for transfer of credentials. This may necessitate the need for an immediate upgrade to the latest version of Accurate which addresses issues with LDAP

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* The Accurate platform is currently running in active-passive configuration across two datacentres, Burwood & Norwest, with manual switch over required.
* The v2.16 instance leverages database mirroring ? Service failure requires failover of entire platform (web, app & database) to secondary site.
* The v2.19 instance leverages SQL Server Availability Groups ? Service failure only requires failover of affected service (web, app, or database) to secondary site.
* DR drills are documented in Rufus and conducted at least twice a year, only simulating full site loss between Burwood-Norwest. Multiple failure scenarios of all components of the system are not simulated.
* In the event of service failure, the recovery process is manual.
* There is a lack of clarity on SLAs/RPOs/RTOs. The RTO for the v2.19 instance is high and is defined at 16 to 20 hours according to the *NFR 16* of the HLSA
recommendations.risk:
* The platform is based on legacy client-server architecture which does not lend well to high availability scenarios.
* Service failure will require significant production downtime to switch over to secondary site.
* Cross site performance on v2.19 is sub optimal, resulting in longer processing times.
* Low automation capability, resulting in longer recovery times due to manual effort to recover services.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Automate recovery process.** Automate the recovery process to lower RTOs and minimize downtime by leveraging tooling & scripts. This should cover all tiers of the platform .., app, web, and database. Automation will introduce consistency, reliability, and overall confidence.
*  **Failover testing should cover multiple scenarios**. DR rehearsals and failover testing should include multiple scenarios covering all aspects of the platform to identify and mitigate against future failure.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* There is a full set of non-production environments for development and testing. The test/UAT environment has 50% of production memory and CPU as per the HLSA.
* All testing currently being performed by the developers.
* The Accurate platform does not support automated testing and only manual testing is performed.
* Upgrade testing includes both load testing to ensure that production loads can be processed in the upgraded instance, and UAT performed by end users to ensure that the platform is operating correctly.
* UAT takes 2 to 3 weeks to perform, as all four hundred accounts are included and testing is manual, contributing to the long duration of upgrades.
* Load testing is performed in the half-sized test/UAT environment, from which production performance has been extrapolated in the past.
* Staff interviews indicated that load testing in the upgraded instance did not detect the performance issues that manifested when production loads were moved to the upgraded v2.19 instance. The 15 to 20 of the largest files that caused 10 hours delay to overall processing, were not included.
* Load testing in the upgraded v2.19 instance detected an increase in processing time of 5 minutes per file which was attributed to the reduced environment size, while files loaded in isolation in the upgraded staging and production environments took about the same time as in v2.16 instance.
* Staff interviews indicate that production processing in the v2.16 instance, which takes 20 to 22 hours to complete, cannot be fully replicated in the smaller test/UAT environment. Consequently, only four hundred of the 600 total production files were included in upgrade testing, and none were the biggest files due to complexity and difficulties obtaining these from production.
* The size of the database used in upgrade testing was smaller than production. This is significant because as database size may potentially be a factor in performance degradation.
* CBA is not part of any known beta testing programme for Accurate.
recommendations.risk:
* Differing production and test/UAT environment configurations increase the risk of not detecting potential issues.
* Because not all production files are included in upgrade testing, there is an increased risk of not detecting potential issues.
* Because testing is manual and time consuming, there is a risk that testing will be incomplete and therefore will not detect all issues.
* As processing volumes increase, with more reconciliations and more transactions, manual testing is going to get harder to perform, potentially leading to more shortcuts in what is tested and more pressure to skip upgrades.
* Because testing is performed by developers, not specialized in testing, important aspects of testing may be overlooked.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Develop unit tests to prove reconciliations are working correctly.** Run them, ideally automatically, when significant changes are made to an environment. This will enable detection of bugs/issues early in the development process. Use a small subset of lines from source files that test all the matching rules rather than complete files, because large files will make tests much slower and there will be a temptation to therefore skip them. With good, automated test coverage comes the possibility of making upgrades faster, more reliable, repeatable, and less disruptive. 
* **Prove that the upgraded instance can process anticipated future volumes.** Anticipated future processing volumes are defined in as non-functional requirements in the HLSA. Testing must prove that the upgraded instance can meet these requirements. 
* **Dedicated testers should be responsible for the testing.** There should be a segregation of responsibility between developers and testers. Dedicated, specialised testers should perform testing to ensure all criteria and results are well documented.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.observation:
* The Software License Agreement, dated 22 Feb 2008, covers the use of Accurate across four environments, Dev, UAT, Staging and Production.
  * The Software License Agreement has a 3-year lock-in period.
  * The Software License Agreement enables users to use the Accurate Thick Client.
  * The yearly License Agreement Fee is based on fifty production users and is 20% of the original cost adjusted for inflation.
* The PSA, covers the Accurate v2.16 to v2.19 upgrade.
  * There were six upgrade PSA milestones.
  * PSA Upgrade project plan has 192 separate tasks covering four environments.
  * There is a lack of detailed entry and exit criteria for SIT and UAT.
  * A Fiserv SME is required to perform many of the upgrade steps as relates to the software.
* All contracts are held centrally by Group Procurement.
* There are penalties for exceeding fifty production users which is audited on a yearly basis.
* There is provision for support with an SLA response within 1 day.
* Only certified resources, of which CBA has none, may create and update Accurate scripts.
* The v2.16 instance, and the underlying OS and DB are out of support.
recommendations.risk:
* Fiserv technical consultations on scripts could become a development bottleneck.
* The 3-year lock-in, limits the Bank?s agility and flexibility to potentially replace the software.
* Running with unsupported software, potentially means any platform failure will not be supported or resolved by the vendor and may result in extended downtime and impact to business.
recommendations.recommendation:
* **Develop inhouse certified technical resources.** The Bank should develop and train certified resources in house for development and maintenance efforts to aid autonomy and reduce vendor reliance.
* **Negotiate future contracts with Fiserv to ensure more flexible terms**. Bank procurement should negotiate contracts that provide greater flexibility related to support and license agreements.
* **Negotiate for extended support**. If performance issues cannot be resolved, this may force immediate extension of support on the existing system while a solution is sought. In the long term, replacement of the platform may be necessary.

finalReport.title:
Lab49 Health Assessment
{{.Project.Name}}
finalReport.content: Produced by Lab49 on {{.Now.Format "2006 January 06"}}, <hr size="5" class="bg-lab opacity-10">

finalReport.title: Introduction
finalReport.content:
{{.Project.Client.Name}}’s {{.Project.Name}} has been identified as a critical Group application. Recent P2 incidents have and continue to occur directly impacting the availability of banking services reliant on channels which make use of the EP system for orchestration; workflow; and integration of services.
  
The focus of this report is the {{.Project.Client.Name}}. This platform performs the following main roles :
* ***Role 1***
* ***Role 2***
* ***Role 3***

The engagement was conducted over a six-week period by Lab49.  The assessment team engaged directly with the various teams within CBA to understand the current technology platform landscape and validate findings against a bespoke Health Assessment Framework to determine CBA’s maturity with respect to the avoidance of P1 and P2 incidents as the Enterprise platform approaches its end of life in **September 2022**.

finalReport.title: Scope
finalReport.content: The scope of the review covers the maturity and health of the {{.Project.Name}} platform. *The review puts specific focus on stability, reliability and recovery from incidents or issues and the overall portability of the platform beyond the end of life. Special consideration is given to consumers of the platform and their resulting experience. The findings provide an actionable path to improvement*

finalReport.title: Methodology
finalReport.content:
Lab49’s Health Assessment Framework is derived from deep exposure to many of the industry’s largest technology platforms; it provides a standardised approach that can be deployed widely across CBA systems to deliver consistent and comparable results. To derive meaningful results across a variety of platforms, the optimised framework primarily takes a 360-degree view of platform maturity including technology, people, process, and data. The purpose of this review is to assess the {{.Project.Name}} maturity, stability, integrity and performance throughout the run-to-retire phase as data is possibly migrated onto new platforms. The findings from this exercise should be read not only as an assessment of the current state of the system but also provide an actionable path to improvement. Furthermore, it should be noted that to achieve higher levels of maturity ({{.Project.Score.Global}} and up) requires coordinated, cross-organisational effort. The assessment framework is based upon a scoring measure across a 5-point scale as an objective indicator to assess system maturity and complexity. The Framework is based upon the following maturity levels:
Level Title Description
1 Initial Success depends on the competence and efforts of key individuals.
2 Developing Team-wide process discipline is in place. Processes are repeatable within the context of a team.
3 Defined Standards are set and used across multiple teams. Organisation-wide initiatives provide meaningful uplift to teams.
4 Measurable Critical aspects of processes emanate metrics and data with high levels of automation. Processes are quantified and controlled.
5 Optimising Process improvement goals are quantified and measured for continuous improvement.
For this review, the following {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics have been identified as key measures for assessing system health:
    {{range .Project.Topics}}
  1. {{.Name}}
    2. {{end}}
Within each of these {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics is a detailed set of measures which have been assessed against the 5-point maturity scale. The assessment of each topic has resulted in an aggregated maturity level for that topic, providing an objective summary view of the overall system maturity.

finalReport.title: Assessment Topics
Scoring Method
finalReport.content:
There are 2 types of scores that the assessment produces: 1. Topic score: this is a score per topic area. Its intent is to communicate relative strength and focus areas across several topics. 2. Overall score: this is a score for the overall assessment. Its intent is to provide upper-level management a general sense of how the service is performing. The method used to devise each of the above scores is detailed in the following sub-sections.

Topic Score

The topic score focusses on providing a relative health measure for each topic area, such as Availability and Performance. It is expressed as a number between 0 and 5.

Method overview

For each topic, there are several criteria. Each criterion is associated with a maturity level (0 through to 5). Some example criteria are in the following Worked Example sub-section. When performing an assessment on a topic, each criterion is given a rating. Each rating, along with its associated score value is listed below: * Not met (0) * Partially met (0.5) * Met or Exceeded (1) This provides us with the following interim values for the topic: * A max maturity for the assessment: this is one level below the maturity of the first occurrence of a “Not Met” criteria. This is based upon the rationale that a topic’s current maturity should always fall short of the first observed unmet criteria. * A base score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias up to the max maturity * The base number of criteria : number of criterias forming the base raw score * An extended score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias above max maturity * The extended number of criteria : number of criterias forming the extended raw score The final score for this topic is then calculated as follows: (base score / base number of criteria * max maturity) + (extended score/extended number of criterias) The final score is then rounded to 1 decimal point. The following sub-section walks through a worked example. Worked Example Below is a slimmed down version of the criteria for Availability topic for example purposes. It also contains a rating per topic for an example assessment:

Maturity LevelCriteriaRating
1Roles are assigned in ad-hoc manner.Met or exceeded (1)
1Availability requirements are collected in ad-hoc manner and are not quantified.Met or exceeded (1)
2Initial attempts to assign roles across development team, solution architecture and architecture review board. Basic consistency on across projects exists.Met or exceeded (1)
2Operational standards are being established with respect to availability, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.Met or exceeded (1)
3Group-wide roles across development team, solution architecture, architecture review board are defined and followed.Partially met (0.5)
3Group-wide requirements process for availability is established and followed. It includes specification of quantifiable availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are established.Partially met (0.5)
4Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.Not met (0)
5Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability. Partially met (0.5)
In this example, the interim values are: * Max maturity: 3 (the first criteria with “Not met” is a Level 4 criteria, therefore max maturity becomes 3). * Base score: 5 * Base number of criteria : 6 * Extended score : 0.5 * Extended number of criteria: 2 Therefore, the final topic score, in this example, works out to be: (5 / 6) * 3 + (0.5/2) = 2.75

Overall Score

The overall score is a simple average over the score of each topic. Supposing a given assessment yields the following topic scores:
TopicMaturity Level
Availability Developing(2.7)
Performance Developing(2.6)
Scalability Developing(2)
Maintainability Developing(3.3)
Security Defined(3.7)
Organisational Architectural Alignment Developing(1.9)
SDLC Process Initial(2.6)
Change Management Defined(2.8)
Incident Management Defined(2)
Disaster Recovery Defined(3.4)
For such an assessment, the overall score becomes 2.7.

questions.definition: How does your team and system define “availability”?
Are you tracking any availability metrics and data?

Are you using any tools or processes to test and monitor availability? Are these integrated with group-wide tooling and metrics? 
a.	Integration with third-parties — e.g., Verizon
b.	Cloud and On-Premise.
Do you have any availability goals derived from business SLAs/SLOs?
What are your SLAs and SLOs with respect to Availability?
What testing processes and environments do you have in place? Do your test environments topologically mirror production?
Do you regularly test different failure modes with controlled experiments?
What is your system’s ARC Tier, and how do you measure adherence to its requirements?
How does your team come to learn of availability issues?
What tools do you use to investigate availability issues?
What other systems (infrastructure, upstream, downstream or otherwise) affect your system’s availability? (e.g. DNS, networks)
Is the system architecture fully resilient, with redundancy and/or replication and failover at all necessary components (LB, Applications, DB, HSM)
is there a service catelog which lists the integration services? How does one dicsover services for eg., do you use service mesh?
Do you send service statistics to the group event hub in real time?
Do you send service statistics to the group  monitoring platforms?
Is the data encrypted in transit and at rest?
Is there a KPI defined for the appication how do you montior it?
What is the process in ensuring the state of the services are always healthy?
How do you ensure you move changes to production without any impact to the consuming applications?
How often is buisiness continuity testing done? How is it done? What are the issues found from the last BCP testing? Did you meet the RPO and RTO?
How does your team and system define “availability”?
Are you tracking any availability metrics and data?

Are you using any tools or processes to test and monitor availability? Are these integrated with group-wide tooling and metrics? 
a.	Integration with third-parties — e.g., Verizon
b.	Cloud and On-Premise.
Do you have any availability goals derived from business SLAs/SLOs?
What are your SLAs and SLOs with respect to Availability?
What testing processes and environments do you have in place? Do your test environments topologically mirror production?
Do you regularly test different failure modes with controlled experiments?
What is your system’s ARC Tier, and how do you measure adherence to its requirements?

finalReport.title:
Lab49 Health Assessment
{{.Project.Name}}
finalReport.content: Produced by Lab49 on {{.Now.Format "2006 January 06"}}, <hr size="5" class="bg-lab opacity-10">

finalReport.title: Introduction
finalReport.content:
{{.Project.Client.Name}}’s {{.Project.Name}} has been identified as a critical Group application. Recent P2 incidents have and continue to occur directly impacting the availability of banking services reliant on channels which make use of the EP system for orchestration; workflow; and integration of services.
  
The focus of this report is the {{.Project.Client.Name}}. This platform performs the following main roles :
* ***Role 1***
* ***Role 2***
* ***Role 3***

The engagement was conducted over a six-week period by Lab49.  The assessment team engaged directly with the various teams within CBA to understand the current technology platform landscape and validate findings against a bespoke Health Assessment Framework to determine CBA’s maturity with respect to the avoidance of P1 and P2 incidents as the Enterprise platform approaches its end of life in **September 2022**.

finalReport.title: Scope
finalReport.content: The scope of the review covers the maturity and health of the {{.Project.Name}} platform. *The review puts specific focus on stability, reliability and recovery from incidents or issues and the overall portability of the platform beyond the end of life. Special consideration is given to consumers of the platform and their resulting experience. The findings provide an actionable path to improvement*

finalReport.title: Methodology
finalReport.content:
Lab49’s Health Assessment Framework is derived from deep exposure to many of the industry’s largest technology platforms; it provides a standardised approach that can be deployed widely across CBA systems to deliver consistent and comparable results. To derive meaningful results across a variety of platforms, the optimised framework primarily takes a 360-degree view of platform maturity including technology, people, process, and data. The purpose of this review is to assess the {{.Project.Name}} maturity, stability, integrity and performance throughout the run-to-retire phase as data is possibly migrated onto new platforms. The findings from this exercise should be read not only as an assessment of the current state of the system but also provide an actionable path to improvement. Furthermore, it should be noted that to achieve higher levels of maturity ({{.Project.Score.Global}} and up) requires coordinated, cross-organisational effort. The assessment framework is based upon a scoring measure across a 5-point scale as an objective indicator to assess system maturity and complexity. The Framework is based upon the following maturity levels:
Level Title Description
1 Initial Success depends on the competence and efforts of key individuals.
2 Developing Team-wide process discipline is in place. Processes are repeatable within the context of a team.
3 Defined Standards are set and used across multiple teams. Organisation-wide initiatives provide meaningful uplift to teams.
4 Measurable Critical aspects of processes emanate metrics and data with high levels of automation. Processes are quantified and controlled.
5 Optimising Process improvement goals are quantified and measured for continuous improvement.
For this review, the following {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics have been identified as key measures for assessing system health:
    {{range .Project.Topics}}
  1. {{.Name}}
    2. {{end}}
Within each of these {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics is a detailed set of measures which have been assessed against the 5-point maturity scale. The assessment of each topic has resulted in an aggregated maturity level for that topic, providing an objective summary view of the overall system maturity.

finalReport.title: Assessment Topics
Scoring Method
finalReport.content:
There are 2 types of scores that the assessment produces: 1. Topic score: this is a score per topic area. Its intent is to communicate relative strength and focus areas across several topics. 2. Overall score: this is a score for the overall assessment. Its intent is to provide upper-level management a general sense of how the service is performing. The method used to devise each of the above scores is detailed in the following sub-sections.

Topic Score

The topic score focusses on providing a relative health measure for each topic area, such as Availability and Performance. It is expressed as a number between 0 and 5.

Method overview

For each topic, there are several criteria. Each criterion is associated with a maturity level (0 through to 5). Some example criteria are in the following Worked Example sub-section. When performing an assessment on a topic, each criterion is given a rating. Each rating, along with its associated score value is listed below: * Not met (0) * Partially met (0.5) * Met or Exceeded (1) This provides us with the following interim values for the topic: * A max maturity for the assessment: this is one level below the maturity of the first occurrence of a “Not Met” criteria. This is based upon the rationale that a topic’s current maturity should always fall short of the first observed unmet criteria. * A base score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias up to the max maturity * The base number of criteria : number of criterias forming the base raw score * An extended score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias above max maturity * The extended number of criteria : number of criterias forming the extended raw score The final score for this topic is then calculated as follows: (base score / base number of criteria * max maturity) + (extended score/extended number of criterias) The final score is then rounded to 1 decimal point. The following sub-section walks through a worked example. Worked Example Below is a slimmed down version of the criteria for Availability topic for example purposes. It also contains a rating per topic for an example assessment:

Maturity LevelCriteriaRating
1Roles are assigned in ad-hoc manner.Met or exceeded (1)
1Availability requirements are collected in ad-hoc manner and are not quantified.Met or exceeded (1)
2Initial attempts to assign roles across development team, solution architecture and architecture review board. Basic consistency on across projects exists.Met or exceeded (1)
2Operational standards are being established with respect to availability, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.Met or exceeded (1)
3Group-wide roles across development team, solution architecture, architecture review board are defined and followed.Partially met (0.5)
3Group-wide requirements process for availability is established and followed. It includes specification of quantifiable availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are established.Partially met (0.5)
4Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.Not met (0)
5Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability. Partially met (0.5)
In this example, the interim values are: * Max maturity: 3 (the first criteria with “Not met” is a Level 4 criteria, therefore max maturity becomes 3). * Base score: 5 * Base number of criteria : 6 * Extended score : 0.5 * Extended number of criteria: 2 Therefore, the final topic score, in this example, works out to be: (5 / 6) * 3 + (0.5/2) = 2.75

Overall Score

The overall score is a simple average over the score of each topic. Supposing a given assessment yields the following topic scores:
TopicMaturity Level
Availability Developing(2.7)
Performance Developing(2.6)
Scalability Developing(2)
Maintainability Developing(3.3)
Security Defined(3.7)
Organisational Architectural Alignment Developing(1.9)
SDLC Process Initial(2.6)
Change Management Defined(2.8)
Incident Management Defined(2)
Disaster Recovery Defined(3.4)
For such an assessment, the overall score becomes 2.7.

finalReport.title:
Lab49 Health Assessment
{{.Project.Name}}
finalReport.content: Produced by Lab49 on {{.Now.Format "2006 January 06"}}, <hr size="5" class="bg-lab opacity-10">

finalReport.title: Introduction
finalReport.content:
{{.Project.Client.Name}}’s {{.Project.Name}} has been identified as a critical Group application. Recent P2 incidents have and continue to occur directly impacting the availability of banking services reliant on channels which make use of the EP system for orchestration; workflow; and integration of services.
  
The focus of this report is the {{.Project.Client.Name}}. This platform performs the following main roles :
* ***Role 1***
* ***Role 2***
* ***Role 3***

The engagement was conducted over a six-week period by Lab49.  The assessment team engaged directly with the various teams within CBA to understand the current technology platform landscape and validate findings against a bespoke Health Assessment Framework to determine CBA’s maturity with respect to the avoidance of P1 and P2 incidents as the Enterprise platform approaches its end of life in **September 2022**.

finalReport.title: Scope
finalReport.content: The scope of the review covers the maturity and health of the {{.Project.Name}} platform. *The review puts specific focus on stability, reliability and recovery from incidents or issues and the overall portability of the platform beyond the end of life. Special consideration is given to consumers of the platform and their resulting experience. The findings provide an actionable path to improvement*

finalReport.title: Methodology
finalReport.content:
Lab49’s Health Assessment Framework is derived from deep exposure to many of the industry’s largest technology platforms; it provides a standardised approach that can be deployed widely across CBA systems to deliver consistent and comparable results. To derive meaningful results across a variety of platforms, the optimised framework primarily takes a 360-degree view of platform maturity including technology, people, process, and data. The purpose of this review is to assess the {{.Project.Name}} maturity, stability, integrity and performance throughout the run-to-retire phase as data is possibly migrated onto new platforms. The findings from this exercise should be read not only as an assessment of the current state of the system but also provide an actionable path to improvement. Furthermore, it should be noted that to achieve higher levels of maturity ({{.Project.Score.Global}} and up) requires coordinated, cross-organisational effort. The assessment framework is based upon a scoring measure across a 5-point scale as an objective indicator to assess system maturity and complexity. The Framework is based upon the following maturity levels:
Level Title Description
1 Initial Success depends on the competence and efforts of key individuals.
2 Developing Team-wide process discipline is in place. Processes are repeatable within the context of a team.
3 Defined Standards are set and used across multiple teams. Organisation-wide initiatives provide meaningful uplift to teams.
4 Measurable Critical aspects of processes emanate metrics and data with high levels of automation. Processes are quantified and controlled.
5 Optimising Process improvement goals are quantified and measured for continuous improvement.
For this review, the following {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics have been identified as key measures for assessing system health:
    {{range .Project.Topics}}
  1. {{.Name}}
    2. {{end}}
Within each of these {{.Project.Topics | len}} topics is a detailed set of measures which have been assessed against the 5-point maturity scale. The assessment of each topic has resulted in an aggregated maturity level for that topic, providing an objective summary view of the overall system maturity.

finalReport.title: Assessment Topics
Scoring Method
finalReport.content:
There are 2 types of scores that the assessment produces: 1. Topic score: this is a score per topic area. Its intent is to communicate relative strength and focus areas across several topics. 2. Overall score: this is a score for the overall assessment. Its intent is to provide upper-level management a general sense of how the service is performing. The method used to devise each of the above scores is detailed in the following sub-sections.

Topic Score

The topic score focusses on providing a relative health measure for each topic area, such as Availability and Performance. It is expressed as a number between 0 and 5.

Method overview

For each topic, there are several criteria. Each criterion is associated with a maturity level (0 through to 5). Some example criteria are in the following Worked Example sub-section. When performing an assessment on a topic, each criterion is given a rating. Each rating, along with its associated score value is listed below: * Not met (0) * Partially met (0.5) * Met or Exceeded (1) This provides us with the following interim values for the topic: * A max maturity for the assessment: this is one level below the maturity of the first occurrence of a “Not Met” criteria. This is based upon the rationale that a topic’s current maturity should always fall short of the first observed unmet criteria. * A base score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias up to the max maturity * The base number of criteria : number of criterias forming the base raw score * An extended score : this is calculated by summing rating scores of the criterias above max maturity * The extended number of criteria : number of criterias forming the extended raw score The final score for this topic is then calculated as follows: (base score / base number of criteria * max maturity) + (extended score/extended number of criterias) The final score is then rounded to 1 decimal point. The following sub-section walks through a worked example. Worked Example Below is a slimmed down version of the criteria for Availability topic for example purposes. It also contains a rating per topic for an example assessment:

Maturity LevelCriteriaRating
1Roles are assigned in ad-hoc manner.Met or exceeded (1)
1Availability requirements are collected in ad-hoc manner and are not quantified.Met or exceeded (1)
2Initial attempts to assign roles across development team, solution architecture and architecture review board. Basic consistency on across projects exists.Met or exceeded (1)
2Operational standards are being established with respect to availability, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.Met or exceeded (1)
3Group-wide roles across development team, solution architecture, architecture review board are defined and followed.Partially met (0.5)
3Group-wide requirements process for availability is established and followed. It includes specification of quantifiable availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are established.Partially met (0.5)
4Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.Not met (0)
5Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability. Partially met (0.5)
In this example, the interim values are: * Max maturity: 3 (the first criteria with “Not met” is a Level 4 criteria, therefore max maturity becomes 3). * Base score: 5 * Base number of criteria : 6 * Extended score : 0.5 * Extended number of criteria: 2 Therefore, the final topic score, in this example, works out to be: (5 / 6) * 3 + (0.5/2) = 2.75

Overall Score

The overall score is a simple average over the score of each topic. Supposing a given assessment yields the following topic scores:
TopicMaturity Level
Availability Developing(2.7)
Performance Developing(2.6)
Scalability Developing(2)
Maintainability Developing(3.3)
Security Defined(3.7)
Organisational Architectural Alignment Developing(1.9)
SDLC Process Initial(2.6)
Change Management Defined(2.8)
Incident Management Defined(2)
Disaster Recovery Defined(3.4)
For such an assessment, the overall score becomes 2.7.

criterias.definition: Proactive alert generation of suspicious activities based on the audit report eg., accessing system that they are not supposed to access.

criterias.name: Processes and follow-up for incident, vulnerability and issue management is dependent on individual efforts.
criterias.definition: Processes and follow-up for incident, vulnerability and issue management is dependent on individual efforts.

criterias.name: Processes established for sign-off authority;
criterias.definition: Processes established for sign-off authority;

criterias.name: Processes for network, host and application scanning and penetration testing are dependent on key individuals.
criterias.definition: Processes for network, host and application scanning and penetration testing are dependent on key individuals.

criterias.name: Quantifiable metrics being measured in comparison with market peers and actionable target set for improvement
criterias.definition: Quantifiable metrics being measured in comparison with market peers and actionable target set for improvement

criterias.name: Quantified improvement goals exist across requirements, testing and incident response.
criterias.definition: Quantified improvement goals exist across requirements, testing and incident response.

criterias.name: RC.CO-1: Public relations are managed
criterias.definition: RC.CO-1: Public relations are managed

criterias.name: RC.CO-2: Reputation is repaired after an incident
criterias.definition: RC.CO-2: Reputation is repaired after an incident

criterias.name: RC.CO-3: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams
criterias.definition: RC.CO-3: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams

criterias.name: RS.MI-2: Incidents are mitigated
criterias.definition: RS.MI-2: Incidents are mitigated

criterias.name: RS.MI-3: Newly identified vulnerabilities are mitigated or documented as accepted risks
criterias.definition: RS.MI-3: Newly identified vulnerabilities are mitigated or documented as accepted risks

criterias.name: Reactive availability monitoring in place - customers/end-users/interfacing systems notify service owners of availability issue
criterias.definition: Reactive availability monitoring in place - customers/end-users/interfacing systems notify service owners of availability issue

criterias.name: Recurrent performance issues are quantified and are fed back through the SDLC for remediation.
criterias.definition: Recurrent performance issues are quantified and are fed back through the SDLC for remediation.

criterias.name: Regular external auditing to check if they meet non negotiable metrics
criterias.definition: Regular external auditing to check if they meet non negotiable metrics

criterias.name: Regular rehearsals and dry-runs of incident scenarios
criterias.definition: Regular rehearsals and dry-runs of incident scenarios

criterias.name: Regular reporting on metrics to surface patterns and opportunities
criterias.definition: Regular reporting on metrics to surface patterns and opportunities

criterias.definition: Release and deployment KPIs are established appropriately for the service. Example include number of releases per week, duration, number of people, impact, cost, success rate.

criterias.name: Releases are performed using a series of manual steps by key individuals
criterias.definition: Releases are performed using a series of manual steps by key individuals

criterias.name: Roles are defined and adhered to group-wide.
criterias.definition: Roles are defined and adhered to group-wide.

criterias.name: Roles are defined in an ad-hoc manner by individuals within the team.

criterias.definition: Roles for Disaster Recovery are defined and adhered to group-wide.

criterias.name: Root-cause analysis results for every incident is captured and fed back into SDLC
criterias.definition: Root-cause analysis results for every incident is captured and fed back into SDLC

criterias.definition: SLA's defined with penalties;

criterias.name: SLAs in place and actively managed;
criterias.definition: SLAs in place and actively managed;

criterias.name: Signs of operatinng model being dynamic and adapting to business needs and market adjustments
criterias.definition: Signs of operatinng model being dynamic and adapting to business needs and market adjustments

criterias.name: Skilled individuals performing in subject specific teams
criterias.definition: Skilled individuals performing in subject specific teams

criterias.definition: Some adhoc availability monitoring is performed but not yet systematic and consistent.

criterias.name: Some adhoc availability testing is done but depends on individual effort.
criterias.definition: Some adhoc availability testing is done but depends on individual effort.

criterias.name: Some availability data is available but may be inconsistent.
criterias.definition: Some availability data is available but may be inconsistent.

criterias.name: Some availability data is available but may be inconsistentGroup-wide standards are set for availablity testing and monitoring tools. Tools are used in highly predictive manner.
criterias.definition: Some availability data is available but may be inconsistentGroup-wide standards are set for availablity testing and monitoring tools. Tools are used in highly predictive manner.

criterias.name: Some availability-related data is collected, but it is not done in consistent manner.
criterias.definition: Some availability-related data is collected, but it is not done in consistent manner.

criterias.name: Some consistency in the use of CI and CD pipelines, SDLC tools (such as Jira), enterprise and vendor artefact repositories and tools, and containerised tooling.
criterias.definition: Some consistency in the use of CI and CD pipelines, SDLC tools (such as Jira), enterprise and vendor artefact repositories and tools, and containerised tooling.

criterias.definition: Some consistency with build or acquisition of artefacts within teams.

criterias.name: Some consistent release metrics are collected across teams.
criterias.definition: Some consistent release metrics are collected across teams.

criterias.name: Some contracts exists but sit with individual team leads;
criterias.definition: Some contracts exists but sit with individual team leads;

criterias.definition: Some data may be collected but collection depends on individual initiative.

criterias.name: Some design principles are followed by individuals.
criterias.definition: Some design principles are followed by individuals.
